Chance The Rapper is perhaps the archetype of an indigenous SoundCloud creator becoming a bona fide superstar. What began as an independent emcee adding a free debut mixtape to SC turned into a Grammy-winning career and a coveted hosting gig on Saturday Night Live. Following the success of Uzi, Post, Chance, and others, fans have even dubbed a new class of performers as ‚ÄúSoundCloud Rappers.‚Äù Acts like Lil Pump, XXXTentacion, Tekashi 6ix9ine, and YBN Nahmir currently monopolize the site as Millennials and Gen Z members repeatedly stream the rhymers' songs on the app millions of times a week. SoundCloud hosts over 165 million tracks, and more than 10 million creators are heard on the platform monthly. The audio service founded by Alexander Ljung and Eric Wahlforss in 2007 has undoubtedly found favor with music lovers and has cemented its place in the modern entertainment lexicon. While the creative side of SoundCloud seemed to flourish, the financial side faced a public relations nightmare this summer. Reports began to circulate that the business laid off 40% of its workers and it only had enough funding to survive through the fourth quarter of this year. Not long after those negative headlines had many users and artists worrying about what would happen to the digital music hangout spot, it was announced The Raine Group and Temasek invested a reported $169.5 million into the company. In addition, former Vimeo CEO Kerry Trainor was named SoundCloud‚Äôs new Chief Executive, replacing Ljung. I had the chance to speak with Trainor about the state of SoundCloud and its mission to enable creators to connect with worldwide listeners. He also discussed rap‚Äôs preeminence on the platform, the Premier Partner program, and the popularity of podcasts. AllHipHop: Congratulations on the new position as CEO. Kerry Trainor: Thanks, Yohance. I appreciate it. AllHipHop: Have you had time to settle into the position? Kerry Trainor: We‚Äôre getting there. I‚Äôm excited to be part of the platform. I‚Äôve been a fan for a long time, since before I had the opportunity to join. We‚Äôre getting settled in. I completely believe in the mission. It‚Äôs an incredibly exciting time at SoundCloud. Particularly for everything that‚Äôs happening in Hip Hop. AllHipHop: I was looking at the Top 30 tracks on SoundCloud‚Äôs music chart, and I noticed all of them are Hip Hop/Rap. Why do you think SoundCloud has become such a popular platform for rappers and rap fans? Kerry Trainor: I think it‚Äôs been an incredible few years for Hip Hop in general. We‚Äôre excited to be part. SoundCloud‚Äôs mission is we‚Äôre here to empower creators and give them the tools to build their fan bases and careers on their own terms and connect with a level of immediacy with their fans that‚Äôs really only possible through an open platform. We‚Äôre all about being first, and SoundCloud is first for creators in terms of where they bring their art to the world. And it‚Äôs first for listeners, in that, if you want to discover what‚Äôs really new and coming next in music, you come to SoundCloud. That‚Äôs why we're incredibly excited to see the huge blowout on the charts this year from Lil Uzi and Post Malone. The artists that are having so much success now started on the platform years ago. The reason is because SoundCloud is the truly open platform where creators can get their start and connect directly with their audience. It‚Äôs unlike any of the other streaming services. I think what we‚Äôre seeing today is incredible growth and progression of these artists who started on SoundCloud years ago. AllHipHop: You mentioned how artists like Lil Uzi and Post Malone first started on SoundCloud. Traditionally in Hip Hop, deejays have been the outlets that broke new artists. Do you feel like SoundCloud has replaced that? Kerry Trainor: I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs replaced that, but it‚Äôs certainly provided a new powerful channel for any creator to have access to a global audience. That‚Äôs an incredibly powerful effect of technology and the web. So for these creators to be able to start on SoundCloud, develop access to a global audience, develop their following, have that following help spread the word - I wouldn‚Äôt say it‚Äôs replaced [the deejay]. The impact of great curators can do that as well. But SoundCloud provided a powerful new channel for these artists, and I think they‚Äôre taking advantage of it by having this direct connection with their fans when they‚Äôre dropping new material, stuff that‚Äôs a work in progress, collaborating with each other, and using SoundCloud to its full potential. AllHipHop: Over the last year or so, there‚Äôs been this new subgenre of Hip Hop that‚Äôs referred to as ‚ÄúSoundCloud Rap.‚Äù Does the company embrace that name for this new generation of artists? Kerry Trainor: In terms of this group of artists, to me, they are about their immediacy and connection to their audience. The way that they access their audience through SoundCloud speaks to connecting with that fan base without anybody else in the way. Our mission is to provide the tools, the platform, and the environment for creators to do their best work. Then we want to be out of their way. So for us, ["SoundCloud Rap"] encapsulates that. It‚Äôs a mission we believe very deeply about, and that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre in the world to do - empower artists and be that first place where they access their audience and that first place where listeners can find those creators doing incredible things. AllHipHop: You‚Äôve been talking about how a lot of artists started on SoundCloud then became stars. I noticed that a lot of the top rappers or the most popular ones on the platform at the moment are associated with major labels. But what advice would you give to an indie artist or an up-and-coming artist looking to gain traction on SoundCloud? Kerry Trainor: I think in terms of choosing SoundCloud to be that first place, there are lots of different approaches, and that‚Äôs what is exciting about it. Whether creators choose to put a work-in-progress out, start with mixtapes or smaller EPs, or collaborate with other artists, there are tons of ways to start to build traction. Whether an artist chooses to go with a major label or a label of any size is totally their option. I think it‚Äôs a great path and makes sense for some artists. Then you also have incredible creators like Chance [The Rapper] who chooses to stay independent, continue to use SoundCloud, and demonstrate that‚Äôs a viable path as well. I think the key for artists starting out is to get that immediate feedback from your audience. You can post on SoundCloud and get those first few comments, shares, and likes. This isn‚Äôt a one-way pipe. This is about a two-way experience between the creator and the audience. It starts by getting that feedback and using SoundCloud to build those first interactions. That‚Äôs what it‚Äôs all about. AllHipHop: You mentioned Chance. He‚Äôs been a very outspoken supporter of SoundCloud. He even gave you guys a shout out at an Awards show. How involved is he with the company? There were reports that he is helping the development of SoundCloud or helping financially. Kerry Trainor: Chance is an incredible creator. We love that he chooses SoundCloud to be the place to bring his art to the world. I‚Äôve been in touch with him and his team multiple times since I‚Äôve joined. We‚Äôre really excited to support him in any way we can, and he‚Äôs been incredibly supportive of SoundCloud as well. So we‚Äôre excited to continue to do things together in the future. AllHipHop: Another artist I thought about is Russ. He uploaded a song to SoundCloud [a week]. He even called himself the ‚ÄúKing of SoundCloud." How do you think his rise on the platform impacted other artists in the way they use SoundCloud? Kerry Trainor: I think it‚Äôs another example that there are so many different approaches. That‚Äôs another powerful thing about SoundCloud which is you don‚Äôt have to release tracks, albums, or anything in prepackaged shapes or sizes. You can do it in whatever way which suits your creative vision and suits your connection with your audience. Whether it‚Äôs multiple tracks at once, whether it‚Äôs spread out, whether it‚Äôs about collaborations, whether it‚Äôs about remixes - it‚Äôs really whatever the creator chooses to do. I think every example of pushing the boundaries of the formats, shapes, and sizes of tracks that ultimately reaches the audience is incredible. That‚Äôs one of the things that makes the platform totally about free expression of the creator. AllHipHop: Another way Hip Hop fans interact with SoundCloud is by following podcasts like The Brilliant Idiots, The Read, Bodega Boys, and The Joe Budden Podcast. They‚Äôve become an important part of our culture. How valuable has the podcast community been for SoundCloud? Kerry Trainor: Podcasting is a huge part of SoundCloud. It‚Äôs not as large as the music side, but we are one of the largest hosting platforms for podcasts in the world. It‚Äôs something that we continue to hear great feedback on. We‚Äôll absolutely be developing something as we move forward, so stay tuned for more to come on the podcast front. We‚Äôre doing more for creators there as well as making podcasts easier to find and consume alongside your favorite music. AllHipHop: Can you give information about the Partners program? What‚Äôs the status of that? Kerry Trainor: SoundCloud Premier is something we‚Äôre really excited to expand. This is a program where artists can have a direct revenue sharing relationship with us. If they decide not to go the route of a major label deal or a publishing deal, they can work directly with us to get a share of the revenue associated with their music. So we support hundreds of artists today, and those artists receive millions of dollars in revenue sharing from SoundCloud. We‚Äôre excited to expand that in the future. AllHipHop: So right now it‚Äôs limited to certain artists? Kerry Trainor: We set up the first round and, like I said, we have hundreds of artists in the program. We‚Äôre excited to expand that and build out some of the tools so we can open that up to more artists. AllHipHop: There‚Äôs been some concern about the future of SoundCloud. Can you reassure the public that the platform is stable? Kerry Trainor: We would love to reassure the public that SoundCloud is 100% here to stay. The deal that we did over the summer fully capitalizes the company so we could keep it independent and make sure we have the resources we need to build out this awesome platform for serving creators. So that mission of empowering creators and being the first place that they come to build their careers and the first place the listeners discover them is absolutely here to stay. The company is in great shape from an investment perspective. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm incredibly excited to be part of it, and I look forward to the next chapter. ‚Äã Follow SoundCloud on Twitter @SoundCloud and Instagram @soundcloud.

The man born Kashaun Rutling then got a bonus package when his appearance as the performer on Slim Shady‚Äôs original "Chloraseptic" hook was extended to include a full verse on the remix. Veteran Atlanta rapper 2 Chainz was also given time to spit bars on the newer version of the cut. Before linking with Em and Chainz for "Chloraseptic (Remix)," Phresher had already recorded tracks with Desiigner, Remy Ma, Jim Jones, and Cardi B. The Brooklyn-bred MC initially gained traction on the net and in the club with his 2016 banger ‚ÄúWait A Minute,‚Äù and he‚Äôs now close to dropping a full project titled PH. Tidal recently highlighted Phresher by allowing him to introduce the world to his East New York neighborhood in the Where I'm From documentary. I got the chance to chat with the DGYGZ artist about the mini-film, his high-profile collaborations, his hometown rap scene, and more. AllHipHop: Your year ended on a big note. You appeared on Eminem‚Äôs Revival album. I saw you reposted a video where Danny Duces was talking about people hating on you for a minute then when you got on the album they started to show you love. Have you experienced people approaching you differently or having a different opinion about you since that album came out? Phresher: Yeah, of course. I expect it though. I never take it personal. It‚Äôs music. Critics and people are either going to love you or hate you. If you f-ck with me, I appreciate it. If you don‚Äôt, I appreciate it too. Hate is a form of flattery to me. I always just try to find the good in everything. Some people wrote me off, and they‚Äôre now back on the bandwagon. It‚Äôs all good. AllHipHop: I‚Äôm sure you picked up a lot of new fans too. Being on an Eminem album is huge. Especially since you were the only rapper. Phresher: It‚Äôs a little different now. I‚Äôm getting people from Germany. I got a lot of white fans now too. They didn‚Äôt really know me before. It‚Äôs broadened my horizons. It‚Äôs like it‚Äôs brought me a new set of fans, and I appreciate that. Shout out to the new fans. I‚Äôm coming with a new mixtape, so they‚Äôll really understand what PH is all about. AllHipHop: A lot of people were shocked when the remix dropped. You had talked about how you recorded a verse and 2 Chainz talked about recording a verse, but I don‚Äôt think people were expecting that remix. Phresher: I knew it was coming.  AllHipHop: Was that the original verse you recorded? Phresher: Yeah, that‚Äôs me and 2 Chainz‚Äôs original verses. AllHipHop: Obviously, Em‚Äôs verse was different. What was your reaction when you heard that verse? Phresher: I was not shocked. I was more amazed. Em is my favorite artist, so that‚Äôs not surprising to me. I know how Em gets when you get on his nerves. He lashes out, and I loved it. That‚Äôs the Marshall Mathers I know.  AllHipHop: You also collaborated with Cardi B. Can you talk about how ‚ÄúRight Now‚Äù came together? Phresher: Me and Cardi are actually good friends. She was supposed to do the ‚ÄúWait A Minute (Remix)‚Äù but due to a lot of bullsh-t we couldn‚Äôt release her part. Cardi B was actually in the video and everything. Some people were hating on her situation. That‚Äôs before she really broke, but I seen it. I was going through it with a bigger artist about her being on it, so she didn‚Äôt make the video. So we just decided we were going to do our own thing. We got together and did ‚ÄúRight Now.‚Äù AllHipHop: Do you mean the official remix? Was she supposed to do the video with you and Remy? Phresher: Yeah, she was actually on it. It was crazy. But a lot of bullsh-t happened and we weren‚Äôt able to release that particular footage. It‚Äôs all good though. Shout out to Cardi. AllHipHop: I saw the documentary you have on Tidal. What did it feel like going back to your neighborhood to shoot that doc? Phresher: That was awesome. Shout out to Tidal. I‚Äôm really thankful to them for appreciating my music and documenting my story. Going back to the neighborhood, the hood appreciated it. I try to inspire people. Where I come from, nobody makes it out. I‚Äôm like the first one from that neighborhood on a big scale, so they appreciate when I come back. I‚Äôm just trying to inspire the young boys and the older guys too. I got good standing in the neighborhood and I‚Äôm well respected. But what I‚Äôm doing right now - they're wearing it like it‚Äôs them on the album, they sing ‚ÄúWait A Minute‚Äù like it‚Äôs their song, because I‚Äôm like all we got.  AllHipHop: There was a moment in the doc where your mom talked about how you decided to leave school and pursue music. At what point did you realize that was the direction you needed to take? Phresher: My parents are big on school. My dad was a thug in the streets, so he didn‚Äôt finish school. My mother was big on education. She‚Äôs in the education system now, so she‚Äôs been a teacher for years. So I told my mom that I could always go back to school. Sometimes you gotta take chances in life, you got to get yours. Some people don‚Äôt see it like you see it sometimes. My mom couldn‚Äôt see it. I had to prove to my mom: ‚ÄúLet me go for it.‚Äù I did it and now it‚Äôs starting to pay off. She never doubted me, but she‚Äôs a "Plan B," "Plan C" kind of person. AllHipHop: You‚Äôve talked about being a big fan of Jay-Z. I think it‚Äôs an inspirational life journey that you went from being his fan to having your content on a platform that he‚Äôs part of.  Phresher: That‚Äôs what I‚Äôm saying. It‚Äôs amazing. I‚Äôm always trying to do what‚Äôs next. It‚Äôs so funny how things work out. I didn‚Äôt see this happening in a million years. When I was doing music, I was just doing it because I wanted to be known, I wanted to be famous. I just felt my character is so big that it‚Äôs bottled up if I‚Äôm not on TV or on the radio. To be on Eminem‚Äôs album and then to be on Tidal, my favorite artists‚Äô platforms, is amazing. AllHipHop: And it happened back to back. Phresher: On Eminem‚Äôs remix I said, ‚ÄúI feel entitled to Tidal. F-ck it, man, I want the title. Submission, they gotta go viral.‚Äù That sat right with Tidal. People were talking about it. Certain people from Tidal called my manager. I had to give the exact lyrics. When I wrote that, it wasn‚Äôt about [connecting with Tidal]. I was doing it because I mentioned my favorite artist [Jay-Z]. It‚Äôs crazy how things work out. AllHipHop: What are your thoughts about a lot of attention being back on Brooklyn, in part because of artists like yourself, Jay Critch, Young M.A, and 6ix9ine? Phresher: This is what it‚Äôs supposed to be like. This is the way it used to be. There was a drought. There‚Äôs no doubt about it, there was a drought in Brooklyn music as far as artists being really known outside of New York. It‚Äôs a collaborative effort. We just gotta keep working and keep putting on for the city.  AllHipHop: You've mentioned that you have another project coming out this year. Phresher: Yeah, PH. It‚Äôs coming out next month. AllHipHop: Is that going to be a studio album or a mixtape? Well I guess nowadays it doesn't really matter. I‚Äôm just wondering how you‚Äôre labeling it. Phresher: Yeah, mixtape, album - it doesn‚Äôt matter. It‚Äôs a project. It‚Äôs getting to know who I am, what I do, and how versatile I am. I just gotta go into 2018 the right way. AllHipHop: Can you talk about any of the producers or features you have on there? Phresher: For producers, I got Reazy Renegade. I got IllaDaProducer. He produced ‚ÄúWait A Minute.‚Äù I got Go Grizzly. For features, we got Jay Critch, Don Q, DreamDoll, Cardi B, and a couple more. We‚Äôre waiting for some things to come in. It‚Äôll be wrapped up in the next few weeks. I‚Äôm very excited. AllHipHop: Those features are very New York.  Phresher: Oh yeah, we got Philthy Rich from the Bay. We got Derez De‚ÄôShon from Atlanta. We‚Äôre working. AllHipHop: You‚Äôve been releasing music through Empire Distribution. Are you interested in signing with a major? Phresher: We‚Äôre working all that out right now. I got some unfinished business with Empire. Then we‚Äôre going to jump into a major situation. AllHipHop: What else do you have planned for the year? You‚Äôve got the project coming. I‚Äôm sure there will be visuals with that. Phresher: We‚Äôre shooting a lot of visuals now. I want to say we‚Äôll be putting out two visuals per month. That‚Äôs the goal now, no less than two. Maybe three sometimes. Some people don‚Äôt even know how I look. That‚Äôs from a lack of content out, so we want to definitely put out more content. A lot of visuals. A lot of audio. We‚Äôre going to really hit the ground running this year. I have so much music. We‚Äôre holding nothing back this year. We‚Äôre letting go. Watch Phresher‚Äôs Where I'm From documentary on Tidal. Stream Phresher‚Äôs music on Apple Music, Spotify, Tidal and SoundCloud. Follow Phresher on Twitter @PHRESHER_DGYGZ, Instagram @phresher_dgygz, and Facebook @phresherdgygz.

Q Money may not be a household name at the moment, but a vid of the Cleveland rapper dancing to his own song ‚ÄúWork‚Äù did ignite the #QMoneyChallenge. After millions of views, it wasn‚Äôt long before established stars such as Meek Mill, Teyana Taylor, and Tony Romo were acknowledging Q‚Äôs social media impact. The ‚ÄúNever Had it‚Äù rhymer is now giving fans the chance to win $5000 in cash and $2000 of Popular Demand merchandise. Q Money partnered with Live.me‚Äôs Cheez for the video maker‚Äôs Dance Off feature. Users can enter for a chance to win the prize by downloading the app and submitting their own #QMoneyChallenge performances.  "We're having a lot of fun creating different features for Cheez that allow us to develop unique partnerships like the one we have with Q Money. It's great working with an artist who is so excited about new technology, and isn't afraid to experiment and create unique experience to their fans," states Khudor Annous, Head of Marketing and Partnerships for Live.me Inc. "The Dance Off feature in Cheez has been a huge hit and users are going to love seeing some of the surprises we have planned for them in the future." Find out more about Q Money and his online ascension in the latest edition of the Conversations series. AllHipHop: How did you first get started making music? Q Money: I first got started rapping about a year and a half ago. I used to sell drugs. Me and my partner used to always go to the studio. That‚Äôs where we conducted business and had people meet us because he was really into rapping. There was a time where I caught a case. So I was like, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm done with this. I have to stop selling drugs and find something else to do.‚Äù So I‚Äôm just in the studio, and one day I was just like, "Let me hop on this song.‚Äù They were struggling on the last verse, so they said, ‚ÄúOkay, go head.‚Äù So I hopped on there and spoke my piece. Everybody was surprised like, ‚ÄúHow long you been rapping.‚Äù I was like, ‚ÄúThis is my first time.‚Äù Then I let my momma hear it. She said, ‚ÄúThat sounds good, Q. I think you should make a song yourself.‚Äù So then I ended up making a song. I started getting addicted to recording. Every time I got like $25 I would record a song. I just had money, but I went broke ‚Äòcause I caught this case. I had to pay for lawyers to fight the case. It was to the point that I was scrambling to get that $25 to go to the studio. AllHipHop: At that point, did you just start putting music online? Q Money: Nah, I never had the courage to put the music up. I was sitting on all that music. I didn‚Äôt know if people were really gonna listen to my music. One day I finally got the courage to put my song up. I‚Äôm thinking when I put my song up I‚Äôm about to crash the internet with 700 followers. I finally put the link out and only got 130 views on the song, so I was disappointed. I was thinking I would at least get 1000 views. I saw the result from just putting ‚Äúclick the link in my bio.‚Äù So I said I gotta find something else to do to separate me from the rest of the people. I found something else, that was dancing to my own music. I was known for turning the whole club up, so I started doing that to my own music on Instagram. AllHipHop: At what point did you realize ‚ÄúWork‚Äù and the #QMoneyChallenge was taking off? Q Money: When I got out of jail, I started recording more music. I recorded ‚ÄúWork‚Äù and then did a dance video to it with a real mirror in my hand. It went viral.  AllHipHop: What was your reaction to seeing Teyana Taylor and Tony Romo talking about your dance and your music? Q Money: That was big for me. That was the last two people I would expect to see talking about the dance and the music. I was like, ‚ÄúWow. That‚Äôs crazy." It motivates me because I‚Äôm thinking, ‚ÄúIf I got legendary people talking about me, then I‚Äôm going to be legendary.‚Äù AllHipHop: There was also a video going around of Meek Mill checking out your music. Did you get the chance to talk to him? Q Money: I actually talked to him right before he sent that video and right before he went through everything that he's got going on with court. I talked to him right before that. He was telling me he was gonna see if the judge would let him come down to Atlanta. If he did come down to Atlanta, we were gonna link up. I wrote him a letter. I‚Äôm waiting for him to respond. They confirmed he got the letter, so I‚Äôll still be keeping in touch. AllHipHop: You put out a collaboration with Cuban Doll. How did that come together? Q Money: We was in the studio. The first day I met her, I was feeling her. We put the beat on and it just went down like that. AllHipHop: Did you shoot your shot? Q Money: I definitely shot my shot. You know I shot my shot. AllHipHop: How‚Äôd that turn out? Q Money: [laughs] We don‚Äôt kiss and tell. You know females like when somebody can dance.  AllHipHop: Do you have any other collaborations on the way? Q Money: I got a few with Money Man. I got a few with my fellow Cleveland artists - my brother Chrisbo185. He‚Äôs from my area. We got some stuff coming. I‚Äôm going through a tracklist right now to see what other people I should put on my songs.  AllHipHop: You talked about working with other Cleveland artists. Cleveland has a long history in Hip Hop with acts like Bone Thugs, Kid Cudi, and MGK, but the city hasn‚Äôt seen that big wave like you‚Äôve seen with other cities. What are your thoughts on the Hip Hop scene there right now? Q Money: It‚Äôs on the rise. AllHipHop: Do you see the city having its breakout moment like other cities in the last few years? Q Money: I definitely do if we all support each other and stick together. We got a lot of different artists. There are signed artists coming out of Cleveland. AllHipHop: What‚Äôs your relationship with TIG Records? Are you signed to them? Q Money: No, I‚Äôm not signed. I‚Äôm weighing my options. But I knew somebody on TIG that‚Äôs close to the label that I trust, but I never did nothing like that. It was one of my friends that I been had a relationship with. AllHipHop: So you are open to possibly signing with a label? Q Money: Yeah. AllHipHop: How did you connect with Cheez for the dance challenge? Q Money: I met them when we were out in LA. We were throwing ideas around. We came up with an idea to do a Dance Dance Revolution type thing. Then we said let‚Äôs make it happen and we went from there. AllHipHop: Have you played the game yourself? Q Money: I was just playing it. I‚Äôm about to hop back on there. AllHipHop: What were your scores like? Q Money: I got like a 5000. It‚Äôs up there. AllHipHop: Can we expect more from that partnership with Cheez? Q Money: Definitely. Everything‚Äôs going good right now. A lot of people are engaging with the app, so it‚Äôs looking like it definitely could be more on the way. AllHipHop: Earlier, you talked about going through a tracklist to decide collaborators. Does that mean you have plans to release a full project? Q Money: Yeah, I‚Äôm releasing a full project real soon. I don‚Äôt know the exact date, but it‚Äôs gonna be within the next two months or next month and a half. Stream Q Money‚Äôs music on Apple Music, Spotify, Tidal and SoundCloud. Follow Q Money on Twitter @q_moneyyyyy and Instagram @q_moneyyyy. Follow the Cheez app on Twitter @TheCheezApp and Instagr am @thecheezapp.

For that chart-topping single, Bruno joined with the LA-based production team known as The Stereotypes. The musical collective made up of Ray Romulus, Jonathan Yip, Jeremy Reeves, and Charm also assisted in providing the soundscape for the 24K Magic title track and the album cut ‚ÄúFinesse.‚Äù Additionally, The Stereotypes‚Äô 2017 included producing Sevyn Streeter‚Äôs ‚ÄúBefore I Do,‚Äù Fifth Harmony‚Äôs ‚ÄúDeliver,‚Äù Iggy Azalea‚Äôs ‚ÄúBounce,‚Äù Lil Yachty‚Äôs ‚ÄúBetter‚Äù featuring Stefflon Don, and Kyle‚Äôs ‚ÄúSunshine‚Äù featuring Miguel. The Recording Academy recognized Romulus, Yip, Reeves, and Charm's prolific output over a 12 month period by nominating the foursome for the Producer Of The Year, Non-Classical award.  By ending the year with three Grammy noms and platinum-certified singles, The Stereotypes are going into 2018 as some of the most lauded music creators in the industry. I recently spoke with Ray Romulus about his squad‚Äôs remarkable run in ‚Äò17. We also chatted about their upcoming work, the profitability of music streaming, and more. AllHipHop: First off, congratulations on the Grammy nominations. Ray Romulus: Thank you. I really appreciate that. AllHipHop: What was it like finding out you‚Äôre up for three awards? Ray Romulus: Honestly, it was a very stunning moment. We all kind of froze when we heard the news that we were nominated for those three awards. Especially Producer Of The Year because it‚Äôs one of those things where you work so hard, you feel like you‚Äôre doing great stuff, but you never think that people are actually paying attention. So to wake up in the morning to hear that is like, ‚ÄúWow! That‚Äôs really crazy!‚Äù AllHipHop: The other two nominations are connected to Bruno Mars‚Äô ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs What I Like.‚Äù At the time you were putting that song together, did you have a feeling it was going to resonate with so many people? Ray Romulus: I didn‚Äôt know the song was going to be as big as it was, but we knew the song was really dope. We all came together and it was like one big party while creating it. Obviously, we were super excited about Bruno having us involved in that creative process. AllHipHop: How did you all connect with him? Ray Romulus: Our relationship with Bruno goes back to 2007 when we were all into songwriting and trying to get placements. They were like our go-to team. We were just friends that were making music every day. We were basically coming up together. Bruno produced and was featured on a song with B.o.B - ‚ÄúNothin‚Äô On You‚Äù - and he got his solo deal at Atlantic. He put out a solo project and became huge. We didn‚Äôt work [together] for awhile. We then reconnected last year. He asked us to come in, and it was like a party again. As soon as we came back in, it was like no time had ever passed. We were just happy for us reconnecting. AllHipHop: I read that you guys were actually considering stepping away from music at one point. Ray Romulus: Yeah, up until like the middle of last year we felt like we were working our asses off, putting everything into what we do every day, and it can be very demoralizing when the results are not what you want them to be. I‚Äôm married with two kids and another on the way. I got partners that have families, and we have to support them. It‚Äôs not like we have a company supporting us to help fund what we‚Äôre doing. So it was like, ‚ÄúMan, we gotta figure out a way that we can support ourselves and our families when the music thing is not panning out. We know we‚Äôre doing great stuff, but the results are not reflecting that.‚Äù But everything was in God‚Äôs time that we were able to work with such an amazing artist like Bruno. That helped change a lot of the trajectory of where our success has gone. AllHipHop: I‚Äôm sure you guys are getting a lot of calls now. Ray Romulus: Yeah, the calls are loose right now. [laughs] It‚Äôs a blessing. AllHipHop: Going through your catalog, I noticed you guys have worked with so many different artists. Do you have a different approach to when you‚Äôre working with a Pop artist like Justin Bieber, a rapper like Dumbfounded, or when you‚Äôre doing R&B music with Mary J. Blige? Ray Romulus: It‚Äôs definitely a different approach because we want to tap into what that artist brings to the table. So you‚Äôre coming in as the canvas. You‚Äôre literally listening and figuring out at what point in their life they‚Äôre in, what they want to talk about, and the mood of the music. It‚Äôs definitely a different approach every time.  AllHipHop: The makeup of Stereotypes is so different culturally. How does that play a role in the production? Ray Romulus: I think that‚Äôs another thing that benefits us. I‚Äôm from a Caribbean/West Indian/Haitian background. Charm is Samoan. Jeremy is German/Russian. He‚Äôs like a Viking. John is Chinese. We come from different backgrounds and different upbringings. The common denominator for us is the music. That‚Äôs what brings us together, so I think that works for our benefit. AllHipHop: How did the Kyle track with Miguel come together? Ray Romulus: We happened to be working with Miguel on a couple of other things. He was in a session with us, just coming up with ideas to write hooks. Miguel had an idea for that particular track. That just happened to be around the same time we were locking in a session with Kyle. When he came in, the first thing we said was, "We have an amazing idea for you." He said ‚Äúload it up‚Äù and jumped in the booth. Then Miguel came back in and fine tuned it to fit exactly what it is now. AllHipHop: Now the song is being featured on ESPN. Ray Romulus: Yeah, that‚Äôs one of the main songs for the NCAA. AllHipHop: What other work do you guys have coming up? Ray Romulus: We‚Äôre really excited about this Pitbull song. It‚Äôs called ‚ÄúJungle.‚Äù It‚Äôs Pitbull and The Stereotypes featuring E-40 and Abraham Mateo. We worked with Meghan Trainor on her upcoming album. We‚Äôre looking forward to developing a couple of new acts. AllHipHop: Have you thought about putting out your own album as The Stereotypes since you have this song with Pitbull? Ray Romulus: Yeah, we kind of look at this Pitbull song as a good launchpad for us to do a lot more collaborative songs and definitely focus on a Stereotypes project. AllHipHop: There‚Äôs been a lot of conversation over the last few years about producers and the way they‚Äôre credited. You even had Sonny Digital saying producers should think about having their own union. From your experiences in the industry, how have you guys managed the business end of it? Ray Romulus: I think that‚Äôs something that‚Äôs serious, especially for the songwriters. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre definitely more involved with the Grammy Advocacy program to help with the rates we‚Äôre getting paid as songwriters from streaming, because streaming is the platform that‚Äôs the leader of music consumption right now. At the rate that it‚Äôs going right now, none of us will be able to support ourselves. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre really fighting and coming together to help let Congress know the songwriters are important. That‚Äôs a serious thing. AllHipHop: We‚Äôre coming to the end of the year. This is around the time a lot of the year-end lists start coming out. Outside your own work, was there any other music or artists from 2017 that you found yourself listening to more? Ray Romulus: I really love one of the other nominees for Producer of the Year which was Calvin Harris. That album is amazing to me. I‚Äôve been listening to a lot of Daniel Caesar. The new Dipset just dropped, I‚Äôm definitely on that. Oh yeah, and Bruno Mars‚Äô 24K Magic. I‚Äôm still playing that. [laughs] AllHipHop: He has a good chance to win the big one - Album Of The Year. Ray Romulus: I definitely think he has a great chance to win that. Follow The Stereotypes on Twitter @Stereotypes and Instagram @stereotypestv. Follow Ray Romulus on Twitter @RayRomulus and Instagram @rayromulus.

Before the 20-year-old Marylander provided exclusive info about her next mixtape, the Tales of Tacobella creator discussed working with Atlanta rhymer Lil Yachty as well as the widening musical chasm between Generation X and Millennials. She also revealed the greatest accomplishment of her career so far. AllHipHop: You were on The Fate of the Furious soundtrack with Lil Yachty. Rico Nasty: That was also spur of the moment. I went to the studio and my boyfriend was like, ‚ÄúYou got this song to do with Yachty.‚Äù I didn‚Äôt know what it was for. He just told me not to curse on it. I was like, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs obvious. It will probably go on the radio.‚Äù But then the tracklist for Fate of the Furious came out. I was like, ‚ÄúWhat the f-ck? This is crazy.‚Äù I kind of knew before it came out, but I wasn‚Äôt quite sure. I didn‚Äôt know if I was on the song alone. I didn‚Äôt know what they were doing with it. I saw it on Twitter and texted [Yachty] like, ‚ÄúBruh, we‚Äôre on Fast & Furious.‚Äù He was happy. AllHipHop: You and Yachty have done a couple of tracks together. He did a remix to one of your songs. Rico Nasty: Yeah, ‚ÄúHey Arnold,‚Äù and then ‚ÄúMamacita.‚Äù That‚Äôs it. We‚Äôve been in the studio. I was nervous as sh-t recording in front of him. He‚Äôs very smart with how he places sh-t and how he does sh-t. It looks like it comes so easy to him. That was my first time in the studio with him. I‚Äôve hung out with him but never in the studio. I was nervous as sh-t, but it was still lit though. We still talk til this day. He‚Äôs a great person. Exactly how he is to everyone else, that‚Äôs how he is in real life. He‚Äôs nice, happy, positive, and smart as sh-t. He‚Äôs f-cking awesome. AllHipHop: I live in Atlanta so I kind of have a better understanding of Yachty. But he gets a bad rap from some of the older Hip Hop heads... Rico Nasty: Don‚Äôt we all? [laughs] AllHipHop: Well, yeah. [laughs] How do you feel about this generational gap that‚Äôs happening in the culture right now? Rico Nasty: The old n-ggas just want us to bring real rap back. [laughs] They‚Äôre sick of this sh-t. But back in the day, music was like all people had. In the 90s, yeah they had TVs and computers. But did they have social media? Did they really have new rappers popping up every day online, blowing up overnight? No. I don‚Äôt know what they expect from us. We don‚Äôt expect this sh-t. Nobody is sitting around like, ‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôm going to blow up.‚Äù The sh-t just happens. People are just out here judging somebody‚Äôs art. It‚Äôs like going to a gallery, walking around, and saying, ‚ÄúThis is ugly.‚Äù Just because you don‚Äôt understand it. It‚Äôs childish. You‚Äôre old as sh-t, but you‚Äôre sounding young as f-ck. You sound like a little baby that‚Äôs mad because you don‚Äôt get what we‚Äôre talking about. The young kids - we speak our own language. And they‚Äôre just not aware. They didn‚Äôt live through what we live through. Everything was so fresh to them, and now we‚Äôre almost at the point where it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúWhat else can we do?‚Äù Because everything has been done. Somebody‚Äôs always like, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre copying‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre influenced by.‚Äù It‚Äôs not even that deep. Get the f-ck out of here. [laughs] It‚Äôs not that serious. Nobody is worried about you or your 90s album. We‚Äôre gonna play you at the parties though.  AllHipHop: I heard your dad was a rapper. Rico Nasty: My dad was a rapper. AllHipHop: Having somebody around you that‚Äôs familiar with the business, did that affect you as an artist? Rico Nasty: My dad didn‚Äôt really share any of his cheat codes with me until he knew I was serious. When I started having label meetings, that‚Äôs when he was like, ‚ÄúOkay, let‚Äôs see how far this can go.‚Äù He‚Äôs 100% on board. He does give his input on the music. Some sh-t he don‚Äôt like, because of what I say. The old people don‚Äôt get it. And some sh-t he does like. He says, ‚ÄúThis is so different.‚Äù That‚Äôs usually what I go for. I don‚Äôt really go for, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna mumble rap on this song. I'm gonna super rap on this song.‚Äù I‚Äôm just like, ‚ÄúDoes this sound fun?‚Äù It‚Äôs just: Am I going to be able to hear this and not dance? That‚Äôs what it‚Äôs about. Am I gonna be able to hear this and stand still? That‚Äôs how I determine my music. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pOTfQ4NjIKs AllHipHop: You‚Äôre coming up in an era where we‚Äôre kind of coming out of this hole in female Hip Hop. Nicki‚Äôs been out here killing it for eight years‚Ä¶ Rico Nasty: Ten years, bro. For a decade. AllHipHop: Now we‚Äôre seeing more female Hip Hop artists starting to get attention. What are your thoughts about where the culture is now as it relates to female rappers? Rico Nasty: I feel like if you‚Äôre meant for this sh-t, then you‚Äôre meant for it. Being a female rapper right now is like getting dreads back when Wale and Waka Flocka were out. [laughs] Everybody‚Äôs doing it. Everyone‚Äôs trying it. It‚Äôs like crack in the 80s. Everyone wants to know what it‚Äôs like. [laughs] The best of the best will make it. Nicki has already made it. She‚Äôs a big inspiration to a lot of females. She‚Äôs not really my top inspiration per se, but if you‚Äôre going to sit here and say she didn‚Äôt influence this sh-t then you‚Äôre f-cking stupid. She was the only person we had. She was monopolizing the rap game. As an up-and-coming female, the big thing right now is remaining humble. You can really think you‚Äôre big sh-t and the next day you can get put in your place. So be humble, work hard, stack up, and be thankful. Because not a lot of b-tches get to see that sh-t. At the beginning of last year, I was not doing anything. I had a baby and I was working a job that I hated. And look now. Look at this. It‚Äôs f-cking crazy. I get why everyone wants to do it. I get why it‚Äôs a trend now. But y‚Äôall gonna see in like two years, maybe in a year, some of these b-tches ain‚Äôt gonna be doing anything but sucking d-ck and hosting clubs. AllHipHop: You talked about your rise on ‚ÄúWanna Know.‚Äù What would you say has been the best thing or the most memorable thing about your music career so far? Rico Nasty: I think the most memorable thing about my career was stuff was picking up around my son‚Äôs first birthday, and I was able to go all out. I was able to be that mom and do everything for him. I had the whole party set up like a Winter Wonderland. I bought him a car. He had a cake with his face on it. Everybody came out. We took pictures. I put something together for him and I was able to afford it. When I had my son, I was broke as sh-t. I did not know what the f-ck I was gonna do. When I started getting shows, I was making like $700 for a show. So I was happy about that $700. I was happy I could take that $700 for a 15-minute set and go get my child everything he wanted. That‚Äôs what matters to me. That‚Äôs been the best accomplishment I‚Äôve made thus far - just continuing to be the best mom to him. That‚Äôs what this sh-t is about. https://www.instagram.com/p/BXGSZXqH2hy/?taken-by=rico__nasty AllHipHop: I was first introduced to you through Jay IDK. He put me on to your music. Rico Nasty: That‚Äôs my n-gga! AllHipHop: I think the first song I heard with you was the one with you and WillThaRapper. It made me think about what‚Äôs happening in that region right now as far as Hip Hop. You seem to be on pace to be the first female rapper to really break out from [the DMV]. Are you ready to have that title on your back? Rico Nasty: You asking me that question got me hella emotional because I‚Äôm by myself and looking at myself. I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúDamn, bro. The face of the DMV? The first female face?‚Äù That‚Äôs an honor. People out here, they don‚Äôt go for bullsh-t. You gotta be real to make it out or good at what you do. Damn, bro. I don‚Äôt even know. That sh-t is crazy. I love that. I love where I‚Äôm from. I love everybody - DC, Maryland, Virginia, Baltimore. I‚Äôve lived all around the DMV. Everything that I‚Äôm influenced by will be on Sugar Trap 2. We got the club mixes. We got remixes of my songs that I did myself, punching on the keyboard myself, staying in the studio for 32 hours straight. I‚Äôve been working hard as f-ck. So if they are willing to give me that title‚Ä¶ f-ck yeah! I‚Äôm gonna carry the DMV on my back with pride. AllHipHop: When can we expect Sugar Trap 2? Rico Nasty: Sugar Trap 2 is 98% done. We got a feature from Q Da Fool. I‚Äôm famous for only doing one feature on the tape, so he is the only feature that will be on Sugar Trap 2. We got more of a ‚ÄúPoppin‚Äù sound and how I sounded when I first started rapping. The fans heard Tales of Tacobella, and it was good, but they wanted me to rap more. Even on the hooks. I get it. Tales of Tacobella was about my life and what I went through to get here. Sugar Trap is like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm that b-tch.‚Äù That‚Äôs the soundtrack. It‚Äôs ‚ÄúI‚Äôm that b-tch‚Äù music. It‚Äôs more of a project than I‚Äôve ever created before. So I hope with Sugar Trap 2 I can continue to evolve. That‚Äôs what they always expect, so that‚Äôs what I'm doing on this tape. It‚Äôs completely different from anything I‚Äôve ever done. I‚Äôm excited for you guys to hear it. Read part 1 of A Conversation With Rico Nasty HERE. Purchase Rico Nasty's music on iTunes. Stream her music on SoundCloud, Spotify, and Tidal. Follow Rico Nasty on Twitter @Rico_nastyy and Instagram @rico__nasty.

Songs such as ‚Äú1 Deep (Solo)‚Äù cover the Blue Collar Gang leader‚Äôs departure from Maybach Music Group and Atlantic Records. ‚ÄúJean Jacket‚Äù allows listeners into the emcee‚Äôs mind as he delivers rhymes as a coping mechanism to manage the unavoidable ills of the industry.  By teaming with Atlanta's rap superstars Migos for ‚ÄúMy Line,‚Äù Stalley lets the world know his smartphone is for closing lucrative deals not engaging in casual convos. Young Scooter - another ATL resident - shows up on the EP‚Äôs closer ‚ÄúGreen Eyed,‚Äù a cut about jealous ones unintentionally displaying envy. With 2017 also seeing the arrival of the New Wave and Another Level projects, Stalley is planning to continue his impressive musical output in the new year. The product of Massillon, Ohio will be back with two more volumes of Tell The Truth. Find out what Mr. Myricks has to say in this Q&A about his most recent release, the importance of paying attention to mental health, and progressing as an artist.  AllHipHop: You dropped a lot of music over the last year. What led to you being so productive?  Stalley: Just having time to myself to put together bodies of work, record as much as I wanted to, and just bury myself in the work. I was in a situation where I was basically working out of another situation. So I thought I‚Äôd just take that time to be as productive as possible. AllHipHop: How has releasing music as an indie artist been different from doing so with a major label? Stalley: It‚Äôs a breeze being able to have that freedom to create when I want to create and how I want to create, to put the music out at the pace that I want to put it out, and not have to answer to anyone or have people question me about what I‚Äôm doing.  AllHipHop: So outside of the business side of it, you felt like you had more creative freedom this time? Stalley: Yeah, 100%. I had way more creative freedom all across the board - visually, artwork, everything. AllHipHop: You kind of mentioned your situation with MMG on the project. Was that split amicable when you decided to leave? Stalley: Yeah, it was kind of agreed to on both sides. It wasn‚Äôt no issues. It was a natural progression just like growth. You know how you grow apart from somebody? It‚Äôs kind of like being in a relationship. Sometimes it just don‚Äôt work out and you grow apart from each other.  AllHipHop: On ‚Äú1 Deep‚Äù you made a reference to Atlantic. I recently watched an episode of Everyday Struggle when K. Michelle was on there. She talked about how she felt like Atlantic seemed to be focusing more on Internet celebrities like the ‚ÄúCash Me Outside‚Äù girl. Did you see a shift happening while you were there? Stalley: You definitely see them focusing on weird things or things that are just trendy. You just see it‚Äôs not focused on the music and the creative part of being an artist. It just becomes about everything else. I can definitely see how they‚Äôre going more towards the popularity of ‚Äúsocial media darlings‚Äù or people that are popular on social media. I tell people all the time that once you get over a certain amount of followers on social media you can be whoever you want to be. You can be a rapper, you can sell clothes, you can be a therapist.  AllHipHop: I noticed you‚Äôre active on Twitter but not as active on Instagram. Is there a particular reason why? Stalley: I had a lot of pictures [on Instagram]. I just started over with a clean slate - new music, new Stalley, new everything. It‚Äôs a new situation.  AllHipHop: Going back to the music, it seems like ‚ÄúJean Jacket‚Äù is one of the fan favorites off the project. That song includes lyrics about how some fans don‚Äôt really understand the politics of the game. How do you personally balance dealing with the negativity that comes with being in the business and maintaining the creativity needed to be an artist? Stalley: Well, I don‚Äôt deal with it no more. [laughs] Thank God. With ‚ÄúJean Jacket,‚Äù that was definitely a song that was personal. At the time, I was going through a lot, and I just wanted to let the fans know they don‚Äôt understand the politics or what we go through. As consumers, they just want the product. Sometimes they don‚Äôt care to get into what the artist might be going through. Sometimes I just want to sit back and chill, take care of my kids, and relax for a second. But they don‚Äôt want to hear that. They just want the music. Or they don‚Äôt understand how a label could be holding you back in any type of way. They might be the ones that's not allowing you to put out the music at the pace that you want. Sometimes it falls on you because they don‚Äôt see what‚Äôs behind the scenes.  AllHipHop: People in the industry kind of have a sense of what the creatives have to deal with. Obviously, I‚Äôm not an artist so I don‚Äôt completely understand your lifestyle, but after having conversations with people, I feel like I have a better understanding than a general person. From my experiences, I often wonder if we, as a culture - meaning the artists, journalists, executives - pay enough attention to mental health issues. I noticed you sent out a tweet about how important mental health is. Can you expound on that thought? Stalley: I actually make that a priority now, to put myself first. I actually focus very much on my mental health and my physical health. Sometimes that‚Äôs the first thing to go before your mental health - letting your body go, gaining or losing weight. That‚Äôs when the depression starts setting in and you see yourself transforming mentally and physically. But I feel refreshed and great now. I feel like a new person. And I don‚Äôt think that the execs, artists, and others pay too much attention to it. I feel like we‚Äôre in a culture where we are always told to ‚Äúman up‚Äù and get over something. I hate that. A lot of times we don‚Äôt even know who to turn to or how to get this help. Sometimes when we go to a big brother, a cousin, a parent, or a friend, they‚Äôll be like, ‚ÄúGet over it. You‚Äôll be alright. Toughen up.‚Äù It‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúNah, I‚Äôm really crying out for some help.‚Äù It‚Äôs tough on us as a culture. Some people might listen to ‚ÄúJean Jacket‚Äù and be like, ‚ÄúMan, that n-gga got some ill bars.‚Äù I was going crazy [lyrically] and it was coming from the heart. But at the same time, some of that stuff at the time was me calling out for help. I‚Äôm glad I put those feelings out, and hopefully those feelings can help someone else. AllHipHop: Was that therapeutic in a way? Stalley: Definitely. I was in my homie‚Äôs studio. He got a studio in his basement, and it gets a little cold down there. He has a makeshift booth built out of plywood. I‚Äôm down there and I got my jean jacket on. I don‚Äôt write no more. I just go into the booth, put on a beat, and just kind of freestyle my thoughts out. As I‚Äôm in the booth, I‚Äôm looking at this jean jacket I got on. That‚Äôs how the song came about. I was in the booth with this jean jacket and the sh-t is feeling like a straitjacket. Everything started spilling out just naturally. I just got so much off my chest.  AllHipHop: It almost seemed like you had a different voice on this album, not necessarily a voice as in the way you sound. It‚Äôs more like your whole approach [was different]. Stalley: Part of it comes from the freedom I had to have that carefree spirit, not worrying about anybody, knowing that when I put this music together there wasn‚Äôt going to be no one there to listen and pick it apart or hint that it‚Äôs not radio-ready. Also that freedom of not writing anymore, just going in the booth and getting my thoughts out, no pen to pad, just being free. AllHipHop: I noticed there are only Atlanta acts featured on the project. Was that on purpose? Stalley: Yeah, definitely. Again, it‚Äôs a transition, it‚Äôs part of the growth. A lot of people might not know, but for the past seventeen years, I lived in Brooklyn, New York. That‚Äôs like really home for me, even though I rep Ohio to the death. Ohio is home too. So moving down to Atlanta in the past year and a half was the first time I‚Äôve lived somewhere different over the past seventeen years. So it was just about connecting with different producers and artists. It felt like home as soon as I got here. Everybody was welcoming. Migos, Young Scooter - everybody here wants to work and got the same goals in mind as I do, and that‚Äôs just to be great and put out dope music.  AllHipHop: I read that Tell The Truth: Shame The Devil is part of a series. When can we expect the next edition? Stalley: Very soon. Top of the new year. Yeah, you can expect Vol 2 and Vol 3 very soon. But I got a lot of visuals coming out from Vol 1. AllHipHop: I did an interview with you in 2016. At the time, you said you felt like Saving Yusef was your best project up until that point. What does Tell The Truth: Shame The Devil represent for you at this point in your career? Stalley: It‚Äôs a benchmark. It‚Äôs my championship. It‚Äôs a graduation period. Back then, I was still learning and trying to figure things out. Like the title goes, I was trying to save myself. But now I feel like I‚Äôve graduated and stepped into independence. These next three projects are definitely, hands down, my best work. I know I said that about Saving Yusef, but this trilogy of Tell the Truth: Shame The Devil is definitely my best work to date. AllHipHop: I think that‚Äôs how it‚Äôs supposed to be. With every album, you‚Äôre supposed to grow. Stalley: That‚Äôs what it is. It‚Äôs natural progression and growth. As long as I can outdo myself and keep pushing myself to be better - and I feel like I‚Äôm getting there - then I‚Äôm satisfied. Stream Stalley‚Äôs music on Spotify, Apple Music, Tidal, and SoundCloud. Follow Stalley on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook.

TeeCee incorporated the traditional sounds of Cali rap with contemporary vibes on his latest project Realness Over Millions 2. That vintage-modern approach presents a 16-song collection that is easily digestible to Los Angelenos as well as listeners beyond the Mojave Desert.  The sequel to his 2016 mixtape features established West Coasters E-40, Ty Dolla, YG, and Staples. East Coast representatives Wiz Khalifa and Ransom show up as well. Of course, the one-time resident of Mid-City also recruited his MVMNT brethren 24hrs and D.Loc for contributions. TeeCee closes out ROM2 with a song featuring his currently incarcerated cousin Big TC. I spoke with TeeCee4800 about his new project. The interview also includes him discussing his early days with YG and Ty Dolla $ign , starting as a DIY artist, celebrities claiming gang affiliation, and being part of the Priority Records legacy. AllHipHop: What does this project represent for you? TeeCee4800: Just letting the world know that I‚Äôm still doing this sh-t and also reaching fans that I haven‚Äôt reached yet. I‚Äôm just trying to get bigger. I‚Äôm just trying to get my foot in the door. That‚Äôs what this project represents. AllHipHop: Since you‚Äôve dropped the project, do you feel like you've reached a different audience? TeeCee4800: I do, actually. I feel like I‚Äôve reached people that I haven‚Äôt reached before.  AllHipHop: Why did you decide to come back with a sequel now? TeeCee4800: When I did the first one, it was already in my head that I was going to do a sequel to it. It was already on the agenda. AllHipHop: So were these all new tracks? TeeCee4800: There all new tracks over a period of like ten months to a year. AllHipHop: You have quite a few features on there. In particular, you do a lot of work with YG. How did you build that relationship? TeeCee 4800: ‚ÄúToot It and Boot It‚Äù was the first time I met YG. After that, we linked up and never looked back.  AllHipHop: You were on the original version of ‚ÄúToot It and Boot It‚Äù? TeeCee4800: Correct. It was actually just me and Ty‚Äôs song at first. I didn‚Äôt know YG. I went to Ty‚Äôs house, and we did the song. I wasn‚Äôt a rapper at the time. I just went over there to record the song with him. The next day he had YG on [the song]. I was like, ‚ÄúWho is that?‚Äù He was like, ‚ÄúYG.‚Äù I was like, ‚ÄúDamn, that sh-t‚Äôs hard.‚Äù Then I met YG when we did the video. I guess Def Jam wanted it for YG‚Äôs solo project, so that‚Äôs when they took me off and did another verse. AllHipHop: You said that you weren‚Äôt rapping at the time. At what point did you decide you wanted to be a rapper for your career? TeeCee4800: It was after ‚ÄúToot It and Boot It‚Äù took off. A lot of people in LA were singing it and knew me from being on the original version. I just took advantage of the opportunity that I had in the music business because I did what a lot of people wanted to do and they‚Äôd been rapping for years. I did it in a week, so I just took advantage of it. I bought my own music equipment and taught myself how to record myself. AllHipHop: We‚Äôre kind of in this ‚ÄúDo It Yourself‚Äù era, particularly in entertainment. But with you being Ty Dolla $ign‚Äôs cousin, I‚Äôm sure the idea of nepotism comes up, like, ‚ÄúHe only got on because he‚Äôs connected to Ty.‚Äù How has that affected you as you move through the industry? TeeCee4800: Of course, Ty helped me in a lot of ways. But at the same time, ‚ÄúToot It and Boot It‚Äù was all of our first hit single - me, Ty, and YG. Him and YG blew up. I‚Äôm still a West Coast legend, and I‚Äôm just trying to get worldwide. So we all did it ourselves. Ty is my cousin and he helped me in a lot of ways, so did YG, but I still did it myself. AllHipHop: You have a lot of West Coast artists on [*Realness Over Millions 2*]. You have Vince [Staples] on the ‚ÄúCrippin‚Äù song. We‚Äôve seen celebrities that didn‚Äôt grow up in that culture claim they‚Äôre affiliated with certain gangs. How do you feel about people that got famous and then decided they wanted to claim Blood or Crip?** TeeCee4800: It‚Äôs crazy that everybody be claiming, especially a lot of out-of-towners. That‚Äôs one of the reasons I did the ‚ÄúCrippin‚Äù song. I knew everybody would like it because it‚Äôs authentic and from a real person‚Äôs perspective. Everybody just wants to do it and they're getting away with it. That‚Äôs what makes it really bad. AllHipHop: You have your other cousin Big TC on ‚ÄúThis Ain‚Äôt Love.‚Äù How difficult was it to get him to record for that song?  TeeCee4800: He actually sent that song to me. So it wasn‚Äôt difficult at all? He sent me the song. It was incredible. It was produced by D‚ÄôMile. Big TC is incredible. He gets all types of good beats in prison. It‚Äôs crazy. He gets better beats than me a lot of  the time. AllHipHop: I‚Äôm sure he has to be proud watching you guys and the success you‚Äôve reached. TeeCee4800: Yeah. He‚Äôll be home soon. He‚Äôs gonna be right here, proud with us. AllHipHop: On ‚ÄúRoaches,‚Äù there‚Äôs a bar where you‚Äôre talking about XXL**. Every year the Freshman list sparks controversy about who was selected and who was snubbed. Is making that cover something you‚Äôd like to achieve?** TeeCee4800: I would love to make the XXL Freshman cover. That bar was, ‚ÄúNo XXL. F-ck it. My n-ggas got the mags." It wasn‚Äôt nothing towards the [magazine]. But they do gotta start paying attention to these real artists out here. That‚Äôs all. AllHipHop: You‚Äôre a lyricist. But we‚Äôre living in an era now where lyricism has taken a backseat. It‚Äôs more about the beat or the vibe.  TeeCee4800: There‚Äôs nothing wrong with that. The Lil Uzi Verts and Lil Pumps are cool. That‚Äôs the young guys. I like all that music. I don‚Äôt bang all of it, but I bang certain songs. I don‚Äôt feel no way about that. But you‚Äôre right, the lyrical rappers are not getting as much recognition. But we‚Äôre still gonna have our fans. Everybody‚Äôs gonna get this money.  AllHipHop: Your album does present different generations. You have a certified legend in E-40, and then you have people like 24hrs. Was it important for you to have that mixture of old school and new school? TeeCee4800: Yes it was. Especially, the old school that‚Äôs still relevant. I feel like 40‚Äôs always gonna be in the game. I definitely wanted to get 24hrs on there because we‚Äôre part of this movement. He‚Äôs another new cat that‚Äôs blowing up. So it was definitely good having the old and new schools. AllHipHop: You‚Äôre obviously close to Ty, but also with Wiz. Are you officially affiliated with Taylor Gang? TeeCee4800: Nah, they're just the homies. Shout out to the Gang. AllHipHop: Realness Over Millions 2 was released through Priority Records. That company has a long, storied history with West Coast Hip Hop. Do you see yourself as the latest extension of that legacy which includes N.W.A, Ice Cube, Ice-T, Eazy-E, and Snoop Dogg? TeeCee4800: Of course. I‚Äôm about to be up there with all of them.  AllHipHop: So where do you see yourself in five years? TeeCee4800: Every year, I‚Äôm moving up. So in five years, I‚Äôll be moved up five times, five levels. I see myself in movies. I‚Äôm trying to do a spinoff of Blame It On The Streets. Yeah, more mixtapes, more content, and more money. https://www.instagram.com/p/Ba18hzln3vi/?hl=en&taken-by=tcdaloc_mtm Stream TeeCee4800's music on Apple Music, Spotify, Tidal, and SoundCloud.
