The new album comes with a major stamp of approval. In 2014, Fashawn signed to Nas' Mass Appeal Records, and the¬†iconic Hip Hop figure¬†took on the duty of executive producing his prot√©g√©'s latest project.  Besides leading the reigns for the musical effort, Nas lends his voice to the track¬†"Something to Believe." Fash's¬†The Ecology also features contributions by¬†Aloe Blacc, Busta Rhymes, Dom Kennedy, BJ The Chicago Kid, Alchemist, and DJ Khalil.  It has been a long journey from 2009's Boy Meets World to 2015's The Ecology, but¬†Fashawn is not taking any time to rest. The member of XXL's 2010 Freshmen Class is set to head out on¬†tour with Exile starting February 26 in Los Angeles. He will close out the trek back in his home state on April 2.  AllHipHop.com spoke with Fashawn about his current music collection, working with Exile and Nas, touching on deeply personal subjects in his songs, and more. It‚Äôs been six years since your last album. How does it feel knowing your official sophomore album is set to be released?  It feels incredible just to still be here six years later. Artists in general have that sophomore slump superstition hanging over their head. I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs the case with me and this album. I‚Äôm happy we finally have a birthday for the album. It‚Äôs been our album for a while, but once it drops it belongs to you guys. Do you feel like you‚Äôve changed as an artist between the two albums?  I think I‚Äôm clearer now about what I want to hear from myself than I was back then. I really know when I‚Äôm at my best, and I know when I‚Äôm at my worse. I‚Äôd be the first to tell you, ‚ÄúThat was a trash verse.‚Äù Whereas times back then, they would have to tell me to rewrite stuff. I think now I have a clear view of what I want to hear and what I want to see. What was the creative process like working with Exile for this album as compared to the first time?  The first time there was a lot more emails back-and-forth. It was like a battle of the emails. I recorded a majority of those vocals in Fresno, California, while Exile would be in Los Angeles or somewhere else around the world.  So the difference between that project and this project is he was more hands on this time. He was there for every session. We were just really perfecting the sound and making sure everything was right for this album. Nas is listed as an executive producer for the album. What was his role in the project‚Äôs creation?  Nas was overseeing every song. Every song that I recorded, I would get the critiques from Nas the next day. He played a major role. I can‚Äôt thank him enough for that. He actually heard the project when I was still initially working on it. He decided he wanted to executive produce it, so pushing the album back gave him more time to flex his muscle. You also have Nas on the record ‚ÄúSomething To Believe In.‚Äù What was it like recording with him?  We actually didn‚Äôt record that song together in person. That happened over a course of a month or so. Aloe Blacc originally sent me the record, and we just tried to build it from there. I had no clue we could get Nas on this record.  It was one of the more powerful records out of the collection of music we had. Then DJ Khalil took what Aloe and his band had done and gave it a whole new lifespan.  Lastly, we got the verse from Nas.¬†That was incredible. I scratched that off my bucket list instantly. It was a phenomenal experience knowing I‚Äôm listening to a verse from Nas that no one else in the world has heard before. ‚ÄúGolden State Of Mind‚Äù with Dom Kennedy almost feels like your version of Jay Z‚Äôs ‚ÄúEmpire State Of Mind.‚Äù What was the inspiration for that track?  Shout out to ‚ÄúEmpire State Of Mind,‚Äù but my influence goes back to Nas‚Äô ‚ÄúNew York State Of Mind‚Äù off Illmatic. I always wanted an ode to my state. I felt like I was finally ready to do that. I‚Äôve done songs about my region before, but I never really did it on this scale. My coast needed that. My coast needed an anthem. There are a few songs on The Ecology that are very personal like ‚ÄúMan Of The House‚Äù and ‚ÄúMother.‚Äù At the beginning of ‚ÄúMother,‚Äù you say, ‚Äúthis is kind of like a love song, but it sort of hurts though.‚Äù Was it difficult opening up about such personal issues on a record?  Absolutely, It‚Äôs like sharing your scars with society. With ‚ÄúMother,‚Äù I remember my manager specifically asked everyone to leave the room while I was recording that particular song. It‚Äôs a touchy subject when you‚Äôre not just doing flamboyant and metaphorical raps. You really tap into your personal life, it gets a little more intense. I wouldn‚Äôt call it difficult, but it‚Äôs definitely different from the normal day at the studio. A lot of artists say they use the recording booth as their own personal psychotherapy session. Did it feel like that for you?  Absolutely, my music is my medicine. That padded room - that place they call the booth - that‚Äôs where I‚Äôm allowed to go insane or express whatever I‚Äôm feeling. It‚Äôs a whole other world in there. That‚Äôs my utopia. I get to create the world I want to see, as opposed to the world we see outside our windows. It‚Äôs a blessing to be able to call myself an artist. I saw you posted on Instagram¬†you recently debuted The Ecology documentary. What‚Äôs the idea behind the film?  The documentary is simply my life through the lens of my longtime video director/videographer Punit Dhesi. I chose to do it with him, because I don‚Äôt have a relationship with too many directors like I do with him. We‚Äôre actually from the same block, and he‚Äôs literally been there since day one.  We really just wanted to bring people in closer to my world. They've been seeing me in action, seeing what I do on the microphone. But they don‚Äôt know why I do it or the people who helped mold the person they see today. When you came out the gate, you got a lot of exposure. Particularly from being on XXL‚Äôs Freshmen cover. Some¬†people feel like that list can be a gift and a curse. Obviously, it gives you publicity, but¬†at the same time it may put a sense of pressure on an artist to reach the level of success of other rappers on the list. Did you ever feel like being on the Freshmen cover put any pressure on you to reach a certain level of success?  I haven‚Äôt felt the pressure. I‚Äôve never felt the pressure in that sense. I guess even when you graduate from the Freshman cover to being a sophomore, junior, or senior, you‚Äôll always be put in the ‚Äúfreshman box.‚Äù Even in 2015, they‚Äôll always say ‚Äú2010 Freshman,‚Äù and I have no problem with that at all. I‚Äôm happy to be part of history with that cover.  Salute to all the guys out here doing their thing. Everyone has their time, and I think mine is now. It might not have been that other year, but that‚Äôs between me and God. I feel no pressure to be able to succeed like anyone else. I succeed on my own terms. You end the album with the bonus track ‚ÄúJust Remember Now.‚Äù What are some of the moments in your life right now that you know you‚Äôll definitely remember for the rest of your life?  February of 2015. This whole month, maybe this whole year. This is going to be a year to remember for sure. It already has been, but this month for sure. Giving birth to the new album will be a milestone in my life.  -  Follow Fashawn on Twitter @fashawn and Instagram @therealfashawn.  Stream¬†Fashawn‚Äôs The Ecology¬†below and purchase the album on iTunes.  http://www.audiomack.com/embed4-album/fashawn/the-ecology

To be clear, Worthy doesn't refer to himself as a "beatmaker." He's¬†a traditional producer and self-taught instrumentalist. The Queens, New York native completely immerses himself in the full creation of the music, and his tracks provide a throwback feel to classic Soul/R&B while bringing in a touch of modern Hip Hop.  AllHipHop.com recently interviewed¬†James Worthy to discuss his buzzing career. The DreammusikGroup CEO talked about his production influences, his affiliation with Jay Z's Roc Nation, appearing on the Centric reality series¬†From The Bottom Up, and more. How did you get involved in making music? I‚Äôm originally from New York. That gave me a lot of inspiration growing up with different genres of music. I was a big fan of A Tribe Called Quest, and my favorite producer was Q-Tip. My favorite R&B group was Dru Hill.  I started researching, honing in on the craft, and checking out different producers. I learned about instrumentation. I was fascinated with the production aspect, and I started making my own tracks. Were there any other producers that you studied? Besides Q-Tip, I studied Timbaland, Organized Noise, and Pharrell. It really came down to anybody that was innovative at the time.  Do you typically work in the studio with the artists or do you send tracks to them?  It depends. Sometimes you‚Äôll have a label who wants you to do a record with someone, and sometimes you can‚Äôt sit in the studio with that person. I do make it an effort to be in the studio with the artist, because it‚Äôs more of an organic feel. You want to have that vibe and make sure everybody‚Äôs on the same page. Sending stuff back-and-forth through email, something could be left out that could be very important to the song. So it depends on what the situation is. You mentioned labels. Can you talk about your affiliation with Roc Nation? Shout out to Roc Nation. I‚Äôm not signed to Roc Nation. My cousin is an A&R for Roc Nation, so we do a lot of work with them. I do songwriting with Roc Nation, and we‚Äôre getting more into the production phase over there as well. You‚Äôve embraced working with artists of different eras. Do you change your style when you‚Äôre working with a more established artist like B Angie B and Robin S? I like to work with artists from the 90‚Äôs or even before that who really had their time, but they were kind of left out of the transition of the industry. These are artists that have made their mark in the industry, so why not give them another hit record? If you‚Äôre doing that, then everyone's going to come to you for that sound.  I also work with a lot of mainstream, modern artists. I‚Äôve worked with Future, Young Thug, and Tip [T.I.]. I just did a record with Bone Crusher. I‚Äôm hands on with the new generation as well. My focus is to bring back good music. You‚Äôve worked closely with Sara Stokes of Making The Band. How did you connect? I‚Äôm Sara‚Äôs producer. I do all of her new music right now. We‚Äôve known each other for a while. We met and hit it off. Our chemistry is dope, and she has a great personality. I love her energy. Once we got in the studio, we never stopped making music.  Now we‚Äôre working on her new album. She‚Äôll be on the new reality show From The Bottom Up. It‚Äôs a lot going on. The show focuses on artists that are trying to rebuild there lives and careers after going through some tough times. With you working so closely with Sara, did you get any insight about ways to avoid some of the pitfalls that come with being part of the entertainment industry? She‚Äôs been through a lot. I‚Äôve been through a lot. Her thing is just to keep positive energy and positive people around her. I do the same thing. She‚Äôs turning over a new leaf, so she‚Äôs letting everyone know what‚Äôs going on. Everybody saw the TMZ¬†stuff, the bad stuff the media wants to put out.  She‚Äôs embracing that, because it‚Äôs all about growing, letting people know your story, and overcoming that adversity. When you see this new show, you‚Äôll see she‚Äôs letting it all out for the world to see.  We‚Äôre letting everybody know that you can overcome anything. The success we‚Äôre having with our single, the success she‚Äôs having with this show, and future successes we‚Äôre going to have - that‚Äôs all God. I read that you‚Äôre making a cameo on the show. Yes, I‚Äôll be in an episode with Sara. You‚Äôll see us in the studio working on our single ‚ÄúSneak Peak.‚Äù It‚Äôs a good platform for both of us. Do you have any interest in doing your own reality show? I‚Äôm not opposed to it. I‚Äôve done other TV work before. I always say if it makes sense, then I'm definitely interested. Everything right now has to coincide with the brand. You also worked with Bobby Brown Jr. Or is he going by‚Ä¶ King Jayare? I don‚Äôt really know what he‚Äôs going by now. But I‚Äôve been working with Bobby Jr. for years. We‚Äôve done a lot of music together. I‚Äôve done records with him and his father. He‚Äôs a good kid.  I found it interesting he veered more toward rap as opposed to R&B, especially with his dad being the self-described ‚ÄúKing of R&B.‚Äù He does a lot of R&B as well. He raps, sings, and dances. He‚Äôs an entertainer just like his pops. You‚Äôre from New York, and you work in Atlanta. There‚Äôs been a conversation over the last week about the state of southern Hip Hop. There‚Äôs some people that say rap music in the south - as far as its dominance - is on the decline. Do you feel like there‚Äôs a very distinct difference between what‚Äôs happening in Atlanta and other regions? In the industry period, there‚Äôs a lot of creativity, but the actual substance or content in the music is lacking. A lot of times, you don‚Äôt really know what‚Äôs a ‚Äúhit record‚Äù right now. It‚Äôs 50-50.  In the south region, I think a lot of the rap music - which could be considered Trap music - is going to fade out. It‚Äôs the same stuff being recreated over and over. I think people are kind of getting over it.  I think it‚Äôs time for good music to come back which is why you‚Äôre seeing a lot more R&B and older heads from back in the day coming out. Even rap music - I think more quality rap music is going to come back. As a producer, I know you keep your ear to the street about the music scene. Are there any up-and-coming artists that have caught your attention? There‚Äôs a ton of them. There‚Äôs an African pop star I‚Äôm working with right now. Her name is Zaena Morisho. She‚Äôs very huge in Africa and overseas. She‚Äôs gaining a fan base in the States right now. She has a lot of other artists around her that are doing very well like Rey Fonder. He‚Äôs a phenomenal indie artist. I also like female rapper Marl√© Blu out of Atlanta. There‚Äôs so many of them. What can listeners expect from you this year? You can expect so many things - singles, TV appearances, films, albums, modeling. I have a couple of singles coming out. Zaena Morisho‚Äôs ‚ÄúOne Thing‚Äù is out now. I have a brand new single with B Ange B entitled ‚ÄúShake.‚Äù That‚Äôll be out on the 29th. I have a new single with Bone Crusher featuring Dave Tolliver of Men At Large. There‚Äôs so many different things. Follow James Worthy on Twitter @KingJamesWorthy and Instagram @KingJamesWorthy. From The Bottom Up premieres on Saturday, January 16 at 10P/9C on Centric. The Hip Hop artist‚Äôs latest collection, El Southside, presents real-life inspired stories of living in the SWATS (Southwest Atlanta Too Strong) told from the perspective of a 21-year-old rhymer on the rise.The mixtape has several big names attached to it as well.  DJ Drama added his influential Gangsta Grillz tag to the tape, and other acts such as Young Thug were recruited for guest appearances. Kap G‚Äôs i am OTHER imprint founder Pharrell Williams provides production. In addition, Squat Beats, KE On The Track, Zone 36, and others constructed the sounds found on El Southside. Kap G is looking to eventually drop a 10-track studio album via Atlantic Records. But before Young Migo lets loose an LP, he spoke with AllHipHop.com about El Southside. The "La Policia‚Äù performer also touches on starring in Dope, Donald Trump‚Äôs plan to build a wall on the Mexican border, and more. Was it your intent to combine your Atlanta influence and Mexican roots on El Southside? Yeah, in my own way. I felt like a lot of people rocked with my first mixtape Like A Mexican, but I felt like some people didn‚Äôt understand it. So with El Southside, I just wanted to bring them to my side of town, let them know what it is. Kind of dumb it down for the people, but still give my type of style. Whose idea was it for El Southside to be a Gangsta Grillz release? It just kind of happened. At first I was going to do an EP. I record at DJ Drama‚Äôs Mean Street Studio. One time I had a meeting with my team. We were just talking about what if Drama hosted the mixtape and it‚Äôs a Gangsta Grillz. We chopped it up with Drama, and he was with it. That‚Äôs a pretty big stamp of approval when you get that Gangsta Grillz on the cover. Yeah, definitely. Shout out to DJ Drama. He‚Äôs been rocking with me since about 3 or 4 years ago. I met Drama on Peters Street, and he‚Äôs been a cool cat ever since. He‚Äôs definitely a legend, and I appreciate everything he‚Äôs done for me. On the project, you feature a few Atlanta artists. You have Young Thug, Lucci, and Cash Out. As a young artist from the city, do you feel like Atlanta artists are open to working together? I feel like we work together. It‚Äôs not really too many people that‚Äôs on that, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not really f-cking with him.‚Äù A lot of people get along. I feel like that‚Äôs what makes the culture go further for Atlanta‚Äôs music. We support each other. You have the song ‚ÄúPower‚Äù with YFN Lucci. Was the theme of the song‚Äôs video based on real experiences? That was just a concept I had. It didn‚Äôt happen just like that. I could relate to it. A lot of it is kind of [based on real experiences], but I didn‚Äôt try to do [what happens in the video]. Your song ‚ÄúLa Policia‚Äù came out before the Mike Brown killing and the Black Lives Matter movement became a big news item. Why was it important for you to speak on that issue at the time that you did? With my music, I want to be able to touch somebody‚Äôs heart. I want the listeners to relate to me. I feel like there‚Äôs not a lot of people still doing that. You might listen to the radio and hear songs about having fun, but you don‚Äôt really hear songs with substance much no more. I just wanted to give that to people. Also, it was based on a real experience I had. Something happened to me the day before. I got pulled over and the police were on some real f-ck sh-t. I went to the studio the next day and wrote that track. Unfortunately, all the stuff happened with police taking a lot of lives, so the song was brought back into action some months later. I wrote that song like a year before it started buzzing. One of the things you talk about on the song is how people treat undocumented immigrants in this country. That‚Äôs a big topic now with Donald Trump. What are your thoughts about Trump saying he‚Äôs going to build a wall to prevent Mexicans from coming into the country? That‚Äôs just pure ignorance. I can‚Äôt relate to that. At the end of the day, I feel like it‚Äôs just entertainment. To me, it‚Äôs not real at all. If it was anybody of color saying that, the media would make it a big thing. But because it‚Äôs Trump, they're not going to say nothing to him. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs our job as artists to be the voice for the people. How involved is Pharrell in your career? He‚Äôs very involved. I just seen bro like 2 days ago. He flew me out to L.A. to work. He‚Äôs a mentor. He really supports me. He tells me, "You need to do this with your music." If he sees anything wrong, he just keeps me on the right track. He played a role in you being featured in Dope. Pharrell actually helped me with that. I was in Atlanta. I got a call. They said, "I want you to audition for this Dope movie." I was like, ‚ÄúCool, I‚Äôm with it.‚Äù I play a character named Fidel. He‚Äôs like this Mexican gangster dude. They didn‚Äôt really want me to play it at first. They wanted more of the typical cholo with a bald head and tattoos all over. They gave me a try, and when I got on set they were happy with what I did. Do people ever come up to you and say, ‚ÄúAre you a real? Or are you a fake?‚Äù [laughs] Yeah, people ask me that. It‚Äôs crazy to have an impactful role that a lot of people remember. I remember growing up watching films that were classic to me. When I see people that were in those films now, I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúDamn, that‚Äôs bro right there.‚Äù I never thought I‚Äôd be in a movie. It‚Äôs crazy. Are you interested in doing more acting? Definitely. One of your¬†label mates, Bia, was on Sisterhood Of Hip Hop. Any chance we could see Kap G on a reality show in the future? Not really. I don‚Äôt really do the reality shows. Shout out to my homie Bia. She‚Äôs killing. She got that song ‚ÄúGucci Comin Home.‚Äù It‚Äôs going crazy. Are there any particular artists you‚Äôd like to work with? I want to work with Kanye one day. He‚Äôs my favorite rapper and one of my favorite producers. I want to work with Pharrell on a song, not on production. We always work on production, but we never did a song together before. That would be dope. And just my partners that‚Äôs around me. You did some modeling for Rocksmith. Is that something else you‚Äôd like to pursue? Yeah, I‚Äôll do that. Anything for the check. Shout out to Rocksmith. I like fashion, so hopefully I‚Äôll get into it more. You‚Äôve said your music is based on your experiences in life. So with your track ‚ÄúGirlfriend,‚Äù are your boys now more cautious of you being around their girl after that song came out? [laughs] Nah, man. I‚Äôm a loyal individual. I wouldn‚Äôt do my partners like that, and they wouldn‚Äôt do me like that. Like I said, that was real. We take flicks with people‚Äôs girlfriends. [laughs] What else do you have coming up in the near future? I‚Äôm definitely shooting the video for my song ‚ÄúMove On Up.‚Äù I want to shoot one for ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Need Em‚Äù with Thug. We‚Äôre going to have new visuals coming soon. Purchase Kap G‚Äôs El Southside on iTunes and Google Play. Follow Kap G on Twitter @TheRealKapG and Instagram @therealkapg. Listen to¬†Kap G‚Äôs El Southside mixtape below.

AllHipHop.com broke the story that Zulu  supposedly made the decision to prevent Shawnna from walking the event‚Äôs  red carpet at the last minute. [ALSO READ: EXCLUSIVE: Shawnna‚Äôs Rep Claims She Was Denied Access To BET Hip Hop Awards, Replaced By Lil Mama] Shawnna split with Zulu, Ludacris and DTP years ago, and by all  public accounts it seemed to be a civil separation. Or at least, that‚Äôs  how the parties involved presented it in the media. According to  Shawnna, that was just a facade done out of the belief in loyalty. Behind the scenes issues over lost million dollar deals, allegations  of owed money, and contract disputes actually forced a not-so-friendly  divide between DTP and the ‚ÄúGettin‚Äô Some‚Äù performer, but both sides  still kept the drama in-house. The closeted problems weighed on Shawnna. The dark side of the  industry became so hard to deal with that she says it killed her passion  to make music. Shawnna decided to step away from Hip Hop and returned  to Chicago to work at a club owned by her father ‚Äì Blues legend Buddy  Guy. After a few years separated from the business, Shawnna could not  reconcile just walking away from something she committed nearly a decade  worth of time and effort. A need to be an inspiration for her children  and seeing female rap re-emerging in a major way sparked the emcee to  rediscover her enthusiasm for recording. She hoped the BET Hip Hop  Awards would be the site of her national return to the spotlight. But  that ambitious move would not happen. AllHipHop.com spoke exclusively with Shawnna about what went down in  Atlanta and her current feelings about the Disturbing Tha Peace camp.     https://soundcloud.com/shawnna-guy/shawnna-getting-to-it  What happened at the BET Hip Hop Awards? It‚Äôs crazy. We put a lot of money and effort into getting down to  Atlanta for BET Hip Hop Awards weekend, so we could promote my new  single ‚ÄúGettin‚Äô To It.‚Äù It‚Äôs getting a lot of buzz here at home in  Chicago, but it takes more than that to break a record. So we were all  set up, ready to go down there, mingle with DJs, and get a good look on  the red carpet. I actually didn‚Äôt even know they were considering me for the cypher.  We were right outside of Atlanta, and they contacted my manager and  said, ‚ÄúWe might have another slot in the cypher, and we‚Äôre considering  Shawnna.‚Äù So we hit the metal a little harder [laughs]. When we get there, my manager says, ‚ÄúShawnna I need to talk to you.  Our PR person just got word from BET that you have been denied access to  the red carpet and the BET Hip Hop Awards.‚Äù At that moment, my whole  world stopped. It had been a minute since I had been this excited about  getting back on the scene and letting everybody know I‚Äôm ready. I was  embarrassed, hurt, angry, all in one. That was the straw that broke the  camel‚Äôs back. A lot of people have been asking me the past four years, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up  with you and DTP? What happened?‚Äù It just brought back old emotions of  the same type of stuff I was dealing with when I was with this label. I  said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fed up. I‚Äôm not taking this anymore.‚Äù It‚Äôs been four years.  I‚Äôve been nothing but cordial about the situation. I never bad mouthed  this company. I never said a bad thing about Ludacris. I just wished them all the best. Knowing that I knew other things  could be said to ruffle the feathers, to play the dirty side. This is in  no way a ploy to promote a mixtape, cause I don‚Äôt even have a mixtape  right now. All I was trying to do was get down there and make a little  noise with my single, network, communicate with people. They just tried  to put a stop on everything. But God is good. We kept grinding. We kept  doing our thing. All-in-all it didn‚Äôt turn out to be a bad situation. But the things  we had planned to do never happened, because of some situation with  Disturbing Tha Peace not wanting me to be involved in it.  ‚ÄúGettin‚Äô To It‚Äù Cover Art There was never really any public discussion about exactly what  happened with the split between you and DTP. From the outside looking  in, it seemed like it ended with everybody being cool with each other. I made the decision to keep it cordial. I‚Äôm not the type of person  that likes negativity. The way my faith is set up, I feel like they‚Äôre  going to get it back from a Higher Power. So, I never wanted to go out  and blast the company or Luda, because overall it was one of my best  experiences in my career. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, there were a lot of things I didn‚Äôt agree with. I  just chucked it up to being part of the business. But something would  say, ‚ÄúNah, this ain‚Äôt good business.‚Äù It‚Äôs no secret I was with them for ten years, and all I had was two  albums. I had a feature here and there, but it wasn‚Äôt enough. People  would come up to me and say, ‚ÄúShawnna didn‚Äôt get the push that she  needed.‚Äù  I don‚Äôt have to say all these negative things about them. The  proof is there. After four years of me being cordial, me not saying anything, they  want to take the position to still try to keep their foot on my neck.  What could I have done ‚Äì me independently with my own cash ‚Äì walking the  red carpet? I know what I could have done if I got in that cypher.  Don‚Äôt get it twisted. But me just trying to network and letting the  people know I‚Äôm back working, how could that have hurt them in any way? I  don‚Äôt understand it, and I‚Äôm sick of it. Nobody‚Äôs over there. I left.  Everybody else left. It ain‚Äôt rocket science. I haven‚Äôt signed any deals. I haven‚Äôt done anything in the industry  since then. If they think that I‚Äôm still going to allow them to have  publishing on me after I broke away from that company, they got s**t  f**ked up. They‚Äôve awaken a sleeping giant. I wanted it to be a situation where we kept it cordial and walked  away amicably. But when they made this move and took this shot at me,  they knocked the top of the pot off. What was BET‚Äôs reason that they gave on why you weren‚Äôt allowed to participate? BET was just saying that they had gone into a partnership with  Disturbing Tha Peace. They came together to present the festivities.  This, in my opinion, is what gave [DTP] the authority to do so. No shade  to BET. BET has always shown me mad, mad love, so I know this had  nothing to do with them. That‚Äôs the other reason I‚Äôm so upset. I know  exactly where it came from. In any interview you‚Äôve seen or heard me in, I‚Äôve never said anything  bad about [DTP]. After four years of being silent and turning the other  cheek ‚Äì to still try to take this slap from them. I‚Äôm not taking it  laying down in no way. To me it‚Äôs saying they still want to go to war  with me. They got a problem. If you got a problem with me, okay we can  address it. We can get it out there. What you wanna do? You can‚Äôt keep  going in my pocket. Are you still contractually tied to them? No, I‚Äôm not. I have not been signed to Disturbing Tha Peace for four  years. I have no connection to them. I haven‚Äôt even spoken to Luda since  before we even got to the split. I haven‚Äôt spoken to Luda since we were  in the studio working on [the intended Shawnna-Ludacris collaborative  album] Battle Of The Sexes. I don‚Äôt understand why after four years, y‚Äôall still wanna take this  shot at me. I have no idea what their next move could be, because I had  no idea they‚Äôd make this move. I honestly thought they were on the same  page as me ‚Äì we‚Äôre going to let what happened between us, be between us.  Let‚Äôs move forward on our own paths amicably. Obviously, I was wrong. Do I just take this and walk away with it? Or I do let it be known  I‚Äôm not going to take this. I rep my city. So if I take an ‚ÄúL‚Äù, my city  takes an ‚ÄúL‚Äù. I can‚Äôt do that. I love them too much, and they love me  too much. Females in the industry cannot afford to take ‚ÄúLs‚Äù like that. If I  win, females win. If I lose, females lose. That‚Äôs how I look at it. So  even if I wanted to say, ‚ÄúAh man, whatever. I‚Äôm gonna just walk away.‚Äù  It‚Äôs not just doing that for me. We already got so much against us. It doesn‚Äôt seem like there‚Äôs issues from your side. From what  you‚Äôre saying, the problem is coming from them. Is there anything they  could do at this point to smooth the situation over? You ever heard of ‚Äútoo little, too late.‚Äù Ludacris knows. DTP knows.  They see me. They‚Äôve seen my interviews. They‚Äôve heard my records. They  know I never said anything negative about him nor his company. They know  that. So why would you take it upon yourself to try and stop me from  doing what I wanna do? It was a complete slap in the face. It would be different if  something was building or if we bumped into each other and had words or  my camp was shooting shots at their camp. It was nothing. The waters  were calm. So over the last four years, they haven‚Äôt given any indication they had an issue with anything that you were doing? Nothing at all. It was: I don‚Äôt speak of him and he doesn‚Äôt speak of  me. When people would ask me, ‚ÄúWhat happened with the DTP situation? Why  did you leave Luda?‚Äù I would just say, ‚ÄúI wish Disturbing Tha Peace and  Ludacris nothing but success. All good things come to an end.‚Äù That‚Äôs what I said each and every time. I am a very loyal person.  Regardless of what people said at the time of our split ‚Äì I mean they  threw me way under the bus. I let them go with it, because the media,  they don‚Äôt care about the real story. They want that story. So I let them go with it, but I‚Äôve always been loyal. I know you‚Äôre in the studio right now putting in work. Yeah, I need to be heard. I need for this to be known. People think  I‚Äôm dead, gone, buried alive. People think I just walked away, I‚Äôm done.  No, I‚Äôm out here working. It‚Äôs just so many situations with people  trying to have their foot on my neck. For so long I was always playing the nice guy. Saying, ‚ÄúThings happen  for a reason. It‚Äôs gonna get greater later.‚Äù F**k that s**t! I‚Äôm done  with that. I‚Äôm done playing the nice guy. If that‚Äôs what I gotta do,  then that‚Äôs what I gotta do. You wanna go to war with me,  I‚Äôm war  ready. Point, blank, period. You wanna leave me alone, then leave me  alone. You wanna go at it with me, let‚Äôs go. Follow Shawnna on Twitter @shawnnamusic and Instagram @shawnnamusic.

The grandson of legendary country singer Waylon Jennings admits to  losing his way to the streets for a while, but when the man Struggle  calls his ‚Äúfather figure‚Äù passed away while he was locked up in 2002 he  decided it was time to take his rap passion seriously. With a goal of  carrying on Waylon‚Äôs legacy and creating his own, Struggle set out on a  musical path that has led to an international fan base that  appreciates his heartfelt lyrics and personal story of redemption. Part of that connection was established by Struggle‚Äôs latest video  ‚ÄúBlack Curtains.‚Äù The song serves as a message to his son, ‚ÄúLittle  Will,‚Äù who actually stars in the clip. The video also made headlines earlier this month after  Tennessee‚Äôs Davidson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office accused  the incarcerated emcee of misleading jail officials in order to film  jailhouse scenes for the video. Struggle, currently housed at the  Northeast Correctional Complex, has denied that he tricked DCSO  officials and wanted the opportunity to set the record the straight  about the situation. AllHipHop.com connected with Struggle through his reps via e-mail to  get his side of the story. The Nashville native also discusses the  inspiration for his video, when he‚Äôs scheduled to be released, and what  his fans can expect from him next. AllHipHop.com: Why were you placed in jail and what is the current status of your incarceration? When will you be released? Struggle Jennings: I was arrested on charges of  conspiracy with 200 keys of cocaine and 300 pounds of weed, but it was  dropped down to conspiracy of cocaine ‚Äúof special amounts,‚Äù and they  gave me 13 and a half years at 30%. The DEA had a three-year  investigation on a suspected drug ring from Nashville to California, and  my voice was caught on phone taps with suspected cartel members. I really can‚Äôt talk too much about it though because they‚Äôre still  going to trial on it, and I don‚Äôt wanna incriminate any of my charge  partners. I‚Äôm also serving time for a federal drug charge that I caught  in 2010. I‚Äôve been incarcerated for 2 years now but I just made parole  on my state charges, so I‚Äôll be transferred to federal custody in  February. I‚Äôll be home by the summer of 2014. What was the inspiration for your Black Curtains song/video? Man, a couple of years ago my brother Jellyroll said something to me  about my son. He said, ‚Äúlittle Will is gonna be just like you bruh.‚Äù And  it took me back to when I was younger, remembering people saying that  to me about my dad. I remember always hearing stories after he was  killed about how he was hustling and he had all these cars and guns and  jewelry. I didn‚Äôt realize it at the time, but my whole life I strived to be  just like that. It was like a curtain blocking my view of any other  option. So when Jelly said that it finally clicked. I gotta change that.  I gotta tear down that black curtain so he‚Äôll have a clear view of his  future. You know I got 5 kids, and I want them all to reach their full  potential and live out their dreams, not get caught in the same cycle  that I did. You know, it‚Äôs dark when you‚Äôre living in the shadows. What exactly was the arrangement between yourself, the  production company, and the Davidson County Sheriff‚Äôs Office concerning  the filming at the site? Well here‚Äôs the real deal, from the horse‚Äôs mouth. We were shooting a  documentary before I got locked up. I was at a crazy point in my life,  facing 30 plus years, struggling to record the album I always wanted to  make, and lay down my testimony. Trying to hold my family together at  the same time. My brother Yelawolf and my whole extended Slumerican  family pushed to get a film crew to follow me and document everything  that was going on, but we were interrupted by the U.S. Marshals. So while I was at Davidson County Jail awaiting trial, we asked to  get clearance so we could shoot more footage. It was a long shot, but  they allowed us 45 minutes supervised by an officer and a public  relations representative from DCSO. I signed all the release forms  saying I was allowing them to film me and interview me. During the  shooting we asked if we could do a performance scene of me rapping the  verses to one of my songs. Of course they said yes, or we wouldn‚Äôt even  be talking about this. There was an MP3 player sitting right on the  table in front of me playing the song while we filmed four or five  separate takes of the whole thing. Then they let the film crew walk me  back to my unit. We even asked if they needed to review anything before it was  released, and they declined the offer. So when ‚ÄúBlack Curtains‚Äù was  released, I guess someone got in trouble for the decisions they made,  and they tried to push the blame off on me. So it is what it is. We‚Äôre  still working on the full version of the documentary. We‚Äôre actually  about to launch a Kickstarter campaign to raise the funds to finish it.  I‚Äôm in prison so it‚Äôs not like I‚Äôm in here making money, but as soon as  the rest of the budget‚Äôs in place it‚Äôll be finished. We didn‚Äôt try to  ‚Äútrick‚Äù anybody. We just used a bad situation to put out a positive  message, and we didn‚Äôt let any obstacles stand in our way. Have you been admonished or punished in any why by jail officials? Nah, everybody up here at Northeast is cool. It‚Äôs all love and  respect as far as the staff and everybody goes‚Ä¶ so far. I mean, I might  end up in the hole after this interview, but we‚Äôll jump that hurdle too. Has there been any word about the suspected lawsuit by the DCSO? Nah man. There‚Äôs no word of lawsuits. We didn‚Äôt break any laws. What  are they gonna do? Sue us for the money that we charged people to watch a  free video on YouTube?! Like come on, for real? If they do, it wouldn‚Äôt  be my first time in a courtroom anyway. Do you have any plans to edit the video like the DCSO has requested? No. There‚Äôs no reason to. We didn‚Äôt depict anybody in a negative way.  The message of the video is positive, and I‚Äôm not going to change that. Despite the story of you ‚Äútricking‚Äù officials, the response  on our site has been overwhelming positive towards your music. Do you  see the whole situation as possibly being a blessing in disguise?  Yeah, it‚Äôs definitely been a blessing. It helped a message that  needed to be heard reach an audience that I might not have been able to  reach. The song, the video, it‚Äôs all part of my testimony. And God works  in mysterious ways, you know? It shows that if something needs to be  heard it will be. You can‚Äôt hold back the truth, and the world is in  dire need of some truth and optimism right now. So I don‚Äôt even care  about the backlash, as long as people hear the message. If it changes  one person‚Äôs life it would be worth a few years in court anyway. So I‚Äôm  gonna keep making music that‚Äôs true to me and hope that it reaches the  people that need to hear it. Any other music projects on the way? Yeah this is just the beginning. Of course we got the documentary  coming up real soon, and we‚Äôre about to drop some more videos over the  next few months. I just released my debut album I Am Struggle a  couple of months ago. We‚Äôre talking about doing a remix album based off  those songs because there‚Äôs a lot of producers reaching out to my camp  right now. We also came up with the idea to do a live album using just  my vocals with a band replaying all the tracks, so we‚Äôre working on  putting that band together down in Nashville right now. I recorded a lot of music before I got locked up though, and we held  on to some of my biggest records, so I‚Äôll definitely be putting out some  new songs this winter. I‚Äôm just riding the wave man. Seeing where this  all takes me. I had a vision to speak the truth and put a positive  message out there, but do it in a way that people would really pay  attention. So just to know that they‚Äôre listening is really all that  matters. For more information about Struggle Jennings visit his Facebook page. Stream/purchase Struggle‚Äôs I Am Struggle album below.

Tha Chill: There‚Äôs been a bunch of rumors and all types of sh*t said about what happened, saying that I beat my b*tch up and all types of crazy sh*t. I‚Äôm in here for a simple probation violation. I was on five year suspended sentence probation. Me and my b*tch were arguing and the neighbor called the cops and I was arrested two months later because I had come in contact with the police. I was at the house chilling and they arrested me. I was thinking that I was going to get right out but I violated my probation. In California if you are on probation and you come in to contact with the Police, that‚Äôs a violation of your probation. I have to finish my suspended sentence but they are only having me do eighty percent of it. AllHipHop.com: I had read reports on various gossip sites that you had beat up your girlfriend. Tha Chill: It was a simple argument. The neighbors called the cops and we were in the front yard talking sh*t. My girl didn‚Äôt call the Police on me ‚Äì it was the neighbors. We didn‚Äôt even know that they had called the Police ‚Äì we left. I didn‚Äôt know any of this until two months later. The cops showed up at my doorstep with a felony warrant and I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúFor what?‚Äù They told me that it was because the cops were called on me and I was on suspended sentence probation. AllHipHop.com: Man, they can take you in as easily as that? Tha Chill: Yeah, it was something I learned. Instead of fighting it, and with my prior record, it was worth it to take the deal just to get it out of the way, so that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm doing now. I‚Äôm just sitting here and getting it over with so I can get out and not be on probation anymore. AllHipHop.com: How much time have you officially served already? Tha Chill: I‚Äôve been down for two years and I‚Äôve got one more to officially go. Time is ticking and I‚Äôm getting this sentence behind me. I miss my family, my kids and making my music. AllHipHop.com: How are you holding up inside there? Tha Chill: I‚Äôm in here doing my thing, with the whole Hub to Dub car (Compton & Watts). A lot of people recognize me but they know that I‚Äôm a street dude first before a rapper. Nobody‚Äôs trying to step to me or be on some bullsh*t. There be sh*t happening but I‚Äôm not involved in any of that sh*t. AllHipHop.com: What‚Äôs your Prison day like? Tha Chill: I wake up at 4 a.m. and do about a thousand push-ups, brush my teeth, take a shower, and shave my head. Go eat some food like oatmeal with an apple pie. I‚Äôll go chill with the homies and see what‚Äôs up with them for a minute. I‚Äôll watch some news, TMZ, and Wendy Williams. Then I‚Äôll go work out some more and then work on my Compton‚Äôs Most Wanted book that I‚Äôm trying to put out. I‚Äôd love to make a movie about it when I get out. It‚Äôs the story of me and MC Eiht on our beginnings and how we got to this point. I think my story can encourage people whether they are in Prison or on the streets and help them to stay out of trouble and how the California system works. AllHipHop.com: Are you able to make any kind of music at all in there? I‚Äôve spoken to several artists who were incarcerated and some even had access to recording equipment. Tha Chill: They have programs in Church. I play drums for a band. There are real talented people in here that unfortunately will never see the streets. We have fun together and I‚Äôve learned a lot from these guys. There are drum machines and other instruments in here but you can‚Äôt just go get them whenever you want them. AllHipHop.com: Your camp recently released a new album from you called Chillstrumentals that‚Äôs on iTunes. Tha Chill: My partner has a lot of the music that I‚Äôve made and he convinced me to not let it sit while I‚Äôm in here. We put together some stuff from my catalogue to make an album and secured distribution through Empire. I reached out to the people on my Facebook and asked for suggestions on a title and so many responded. One of them hit me on my inbox and suggested Chillstrumentals. I thought it was good idea to do something like Pete Rock and play a beat before a song comes on. I also put some cuts from my 1st Generation(includes Kurupt, Jayo Felony, King T, Sir Jinx, MC Eiht, DJ Battlecat, Gangsta) group on there to just let people know that we still plan on rocking together. We just all want to be present. I want people to hear my talents as a Producer. A lot of people think that I just rap. Then there are those that think that I just produce and don‚Äôt rap. Chillstrumentals is just a reminder to people while I‚Äôm away of what I can still do. AllHipHop.com: I‚Äôm glad that 1st Generation is still in the plans because I honestly gave up on it. Tha Chill: Nah, what happened was Gangsta (formerly of Tha Comrads) went to jail and we were waiting on him to get out. Then Jayo Felony went to jail too. It‚Äôs crazy because I‚Äôm trying to keep all of my homies out of jail and I end up here. We‚Äôve got priors and that‚Äôs California for you. I spoke with the other members and we decided that we are still going to do it but we need everybody present for it.

It‚Äôs called Beach House the EP. I‚Äôm keeping the Beach House name because it was successful as a free Mixtape series but now I want to make it as something that I can sell. It‚Äôs going for Pre-Sale on January 7 and available on January 20.  You probably should‚Äôve started selling your projects from the start.   I wish I did but there were still a lot of people out there unaware of me. The free Mixtapes were for advertising.  So what‚Äôs in for us on the new EP?  Avatar 2.  Avatar 2?  It‚Äôs a sequel to Avatar ‚Äì the best movie (laughs). Oh I see. You‚Äôre going James Cameron on us. What about an official album? I hope to have that done by June of 2014 so I can take the summer. I‚Äôm just trying to perfect it and it to the next level from Beach House the EP, because the EP is on another level than the Mixtapes.  Earlier on stage, you jumped on the MPC and started playing something and you told the crowd that you produced YG‚Äôs first hit, ‚ÄúToot It and Boot It.‚Äù  I produced ‚ÄúToot It and Boot It‚Äù and half of the songs on Beach House 1 and 2 ‚Äì just like on the upcoming EP.  A lot of people don‚Äôt know of your producing side. I actually taught DJ Mustard how to produce. I gave him the sounds and he passed me up on producing ‚Äì so shout out to him. That‚Äôs my little n*gga, ya know? He teaches me sh*t now.  The Student surpassed the Teacher. Exactly.  You and DJ Mustard created a new path for artists on the West Coast, because there was a time when artists from the West couldn‚Äôt get on the radio, and that started to change after the ‚ÄúToot It and Boot It‚Äù song.  My big homie Big D, he put us all together; Me, YG, and DJ Mustard. We were all up at my old house in Baldwin Hills, at the top of the hill, and we would make music every day. We came up with this sound and people later on ended up calling it the Ratchet sound.  Were you following a blueprint?  Not really. I was listening to the Atlanta stuff because it was real popular at the time with 808‚Äôs and snaps. I took that and sped it up to how we were listening to music out here. The Bay was popping with the Hyphy sound at that time. I was on that same speed but I took the Atlanta drums and mixed it with samples because I love to sample. I like J. Dilla and producers like that. I took a little sample mixed it with some drums and made ‚ÄúToot It and Boot It.‚Äù From there I just started exploring and made different types of beats from House to Cabana. DJ Mustard told me that I was tripping and to just make club sh*t and he went off on that route. Do you think that you get enough credit on the West Coast?  It‚Äôs cool. I don‚Äôt care about that. I want to make good music and they are going to recognize it. The music will speak for itself. I‚Äôm not one of those dudes that will trip off it and try to get attention ‚Äì I don‚Äôt give a f*ck. I‚Äôm going to make good music and all of my family is going to eat.  I ask that because I saw a post on your Twitter feed where you were talking about Ty Dolla $ign and DJ Mustard imitators out there.  That post was about others making up their own sh*t. That‚Äôs what we were trying to do. If it starts growing that‚Äôs cool, but try to make a new sound. I‚Äôm never going to try to copy what‚Äôs out and I felt that was the problem with music for the longest time. No matter which producer is hot at the moment, you‚Äôve got a bunch of others trying to copy their sound. Everybody is copying each other but its better when everybody does their own sh*t. If you go back to the 70‚Äôs and listen to groups like Lakeside, The Isley Brothers and Earth, Wind and Fire ‚Äì they all had their own sound. We are the Pushaz Ink band and we make our sound, and so all of the other n*ggas that copy what we do, they lose ‚Äì straight up. They say imitation is a form of flattery though.  It definitely shows that we are doing our sh*t. Really, I‚Äôm glad to see dudes from L.A. on. When you look back at Snoop Dogg when he first came out, everybody was trying to copy the Death Row sound. It‚Äôs cool that we are out here and we are the new Death Row and these other n*ggas are like Ruthless (laughs). No disrespect to Eazy-E ‚Äì shout out to him and what he did. I‚Äôm just saying some real sh*t. Dr. Dre had his sound and everybody else was trying to copy him. Then Dre came out with a different sound on Chronic 2001 and everybody started to copy that too. N*ggas be biting. That sh*t is weak.  What‚Äôs next for your sound?  I‚Äôve got a new sound on the EP. There‚Äôs the club sh*t too like on Paranoid and the remix. I hooked up with Young Chop and I‚Äôve got one of his beats on there. I got some sh*t with Cardo but the sample didn‚Äôt get cleared so I grabbed my guitar, my other homie got on bass, another played the organ and violin and we created something new that sounds like a sample. You can‚Äôt stop this.  You made a few songs with Terrace Martin that had a jazzy vibe and I think that‚Äôs a good style for you.   Thanks. That‚Äôs where I kind of originated. Out here in Los Angeles, there is a station called KCRW with a DJ named Garth Trinidad ‚Äì a mixture of soul and hip-hop sh*t. Also, back in the day I used to sing background for Sa-Ra Creative Partners. I listen to J. Dilla and all that type of sh*t so that‚Äôs what I love and like to do ‚Äì but the people really like what I‚Äôm doing right now, so I‚Äôm going to keep on doing it (laughs).  Earlier, you brought out Wiz Khalifa during your performance.  That‚Äôs my big homie in the Taylor Gang. I hit Wiz up to see if he was in town for the show and he was like, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up n*gga? Happy Turkey Day.‚Äù He definitely came out and killed it.

Undefeated East Los Angeles born and bred prospect Seniesa "Superbad" Estrada (5-0, 1KO) will be fighting veteran fighter Selene Lopez (3-4-3, 1 KO) of Los Mochis, Mexico in a 6 round flyweight battle. The newly white blond Estrada was as affable as ever at the final press conference for the HBO Championship Boxing event, asking the crowd if they were ready for "the big drama show," and thanking K2 Promotions for allowing her to fight once again at The Forum in what has been a "sixteen year journey" for the 23 year old female prospect.  In what Loeffler termed as a sure fire fan friendly "barn burner," former WBO World Female Flyweight champion Kenia Enriquez (51-1, 7KOs) of Tijuana, Mexico will face off against world ranked contender Amaris "Diamond Girl" Quintana (9-2, 1KO) in an 8 round junior lightweight battle. Fiend has been through it all. The Louisiana native talks about surviving the New Orleans streets, his 24-year career and time spent on No Limit Records. (AllHipHop Features) Although the early 90‚Äôs New Orleans rap scene was predominantly held down by Cash Money Records, another locally owned record label by the name of Big Boy Records slowly created an exceptional roster headlined by Mystikal. Along with the, then ‚Äúbraided up pimp‚Äù was a raspy voiced self-proclaimed, ‚ÄúBaddest Motherfucker Alive,‚Äù Fiend. That would be the single that burst, Fiend (New Orleans native) onto the scene. His first album, ‚ÄúI Won‚Äôt Be Denied,‚Äù released in 1995 was a local classic. Fiend, would find national success 3-years later after signing with Master P‚Äôs, No Limit Records. After appearances on several No Limit projects he released his first studio album on the label in 1998 entitled, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs One In Every Family,‚Äù which peaked at No. 8 on the Billboard 200 and No. 1 on the Top R&B-Hip Hop Albums chart. Fiend would go on to enjoy much success under the No Limit banner and had hit collaborations with the likes of Mystikal, Master P, Snoop Dogg, Mac and Mia X. During a brief stint on the Ruff Ryders label, he collaborated with the legendary Memphis group, Three Six Mafia on a track titled, ‚ÄúTouched Wit It.‚Äù With more than 10-studio albums to his credit and a 24-year career under his belt, Fiend, much like his popular track with now deceased, Mr. Magic, has been through it all. He‚Äôs seen the peaks and valleys of being an artist/producer and much like the No Limit Tank in the 90‚Äôs, he continues to march on and soldier through the good and the bad that this industry has to offer. I had a chance to speak with ‚ÄúMr. Whomp Whomp,‚Äù to discuss his first interaction with Master P, KLC, Mia X and Kane and Abel‚Äôs influence on getting him TO No Limit Records and holding his own lyrically on great rosters. AllHipHop.com: In the early 90‚Äôs, when you hit the scene, being called a fiend was an insult, but you made it work. Where did the name, Fiend come from? Fiend: I looked up to the greats that came before me like, Rakim. He called himself ‚ÄúThe Microphone Fiend.‚Äù Fiend just seemed to stick, and I made it more about fiending to take care of my family, fiending to better myself or fiending to bust rhymes. I was fiending to battle cats and annihilate them on the microphone. AllHipHop.com: You are 24-years into your career. How did you stick around this game for so long? Fiend: How I have stayed in this business for so long and kept my head high is I stayed ‚Äúfuck boy‚Äù free. I stayed ‚Äúfuck boy‚Äù and ‚Äúfuck girl‚Äù free. You don‚Äôt have to be running with the in-crowd just because they are the in-crowd. Sometimes you have to be in the in-crowd even if you‚Äôre dolo. I‚Äôm well-grounded and that‚Äôs what works for me. I move around, I‚Äôm the type of dude that‚Äôs always moved without any kind of security. Not so much that I didn‚Äôt need it to maneuver a lil bit at certain heights of my career, but I just thought it was crazy to hire somebody that is ready to die for me at a certain wage. It‚Äôs like, how is this going to go? I‚Äôve always had great parents, great family and great friendships. I never jeopardized anything for the in-crowd. AllHipHop.com: The title of your debut album was, ‚ÄúWon‚Äôt Be Denied.‚Äù Was that the mentality coming into this game? Fiend: Yeah, I was going through a real unique time. I went through a lot of losses and that was just my goal. I didn‚Äôt know what could have been before me but being a cat from Louisiana‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre just not scared of a lot of things. I felt like I had survived the warzone. I survived this neighborhood; I survived school and my teachers being on strike. I done sat at bus stops hoping and praying that I make it home. I had been through so much I just felt like, as long as I can block out all of that noise and keep going, with nothing on the other side of fear, I could get there. I have a song with the late, Mr. Magic called, ‚ÄúBeen Through It All.‚Äù I was a kid in the passenger seat, so it allowed me to be able to talk about a lot of things. I seen a lot of things and experienced a lot of things, so ‚ÄúBeen Through It All‚Äù with the late, Magic is a title than can describe then up until now. It‚Äôs relatable. AllHipHop.com: Most will remember you from your days with No Limit, but I go back to the Big Boy Records days with, Mystikal, The Ghetto Twiinz, Black Menace, Partners N Crime and that was a hell of a lineup as well. You have always been able to hold your own lyrically while being a part of some great lineups; whether with Big Boy or No Limit. Fiend: Right! I think iron sharpens iron and steel sharpens steel. I think the creative ancestors were just with me the whole time. At one point and time, it was like, ‚ÄúSon, I want you to be great and by all means you‚Äôre going to have to get there. You‚Äôre going to be able to predict the time it takes to get there, but I had to continue pushing.‚Äù I had a passion that ran so deeply I never monitored the time. I was just doing what I was doing. I firmly believe that, when you tap into something, this super power that I feel like everybody from Louisiana possess, I think it attracts that other type of light. That other type of great energy for whatever attribute you need to help push you to the next level. AllHipHop.com: Most, if not all of No Limits albums started with the all-star cast spitting a verse for the intro of the album. With the talent there, you, Mia X, Mystikal once again, Silkk The Shocker, P, C-Murder, Mac, how did you guys keep the egos in check and the jealousy down? Fiend: How do you keep the egos down when you have all of these great artists and everyone wants their turn and their look? We genuinely all cared for each other. Outside of music we were pretty much familiar with each other. That played a very very big part. Of course, there were times where you wanted to be promoted more or get more exposure or pay and things like that; not so much compared to anyone else, but to grow as an artist. I can‚Äôt speak for everybody, but I will say it really helps when everyone has a genuine type of love for each other. I think that made it that much more easy for us all to stand and cross over that bridge together as far as all of these artists chasing their dream and pursuing their dream. I believe that everyone gets their turn depending on the type of work they put in when it‚Äôs your turn. AllHipHop.com: When you have 10 artists on one track, was there a process to the order in which you appeared on that intro? Take for instance, ‚ÄòMake Em Say Ugh,‚Äù how was that order selected? Fiend: There were times where we got together and it was like, ‚ÄúThis-this-this and this.‚Äù But, most of the time we just was gelling. That just was that. AllHipHop.com: Do you remember the first time you met, Master P? Fiend: Believe it or not, I saw him‚Ä¶ my buddy Damian had took me to a concert at the Riverboat Hallelujah. Funny- funny- funny, P was in there selling their music and performing. I was like, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs dope!‚Äù My buddy, Damian liked this, Master P dude. I didn‚Äôt get into the music like that. I couldn‚Äôt recall so many songs and this that or the other. Damian was my dawg, so I was just going with him. I knew Mia. I go to it like any other concert. We get up in that thang, you know what I‚Äôm saying. And, I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòThis is cool. This is who Mia with right now.‚Äù I go to support and buy a CD or cassette, I bought it from, Percy Miller. He was behind the table selling his stuff. He got these high socks up to his knees and I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúThis dude must be from somewhere else.‚Äù I wasn‚Äôt dissing him or nothing I just thought the cat was from somewhere else. I didn‚Äôt know he was from home, ya heard me. I bought his stuff I bought Mia stuff. I‚Äôm just supporting because I think this is dope. These people out here selling their own music; this is the era I‚Äôm from. That‚Äôs when I first met him. He probably don‚Äôt even remember that. My buddy, Damian was trippin that I ended up getting with people who he had been supporting since ‚Äú99 Ways To Die,‚Äù you know what I mean? AllHipHop.com: That‚Äôs crazy. Okay, that was your first time meeting, Master P, but how did you become a, No Limit Soldier?‚Äù Fiend: What happened was, I was working with Kane and Abel, I was working with KLC and I was working with Mia. Mia had brought me to get on one of her projects. She had wanted me and Mac on one of her projects. What we did was we ended up working that out. This guy by the name of Corey Bush, a good friend of ours was like, ‚ÄúI go to school with him. I‚Äôm in college with him.‚Äù He had just started going to college at SUNO. So, Corey‚Ä¶ we fresh out of high school or still in high school like 12thgrade. He came and got me and was like, ‚ÄúMia want to sit down with you and get you on something.‚Äù I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs dope.‚Äù So, I met Mia at like Schwegmann‚Äôs [grocery store] or something (laughing). We walking through Schwegmann‚Äôs getting her groceries. She was like, ‚ÄúYeah baby, I want to get you on my album. I think you dope. I got a song I want to get you and Mac on.‚Äù And I‚Äôm like, this is cool. I‚Äôm walking through Schwegmann‚Äôs grocery shopping with Mia right now. It was so ill. It was too cool, bruh. She said she was going to get me out there to the studio. She came to my house, I guess to vibe with me or for me to run my verse to her or something. She came to my mom‚Äôs house and I remember me and Mac getting up even more so after she put us together.¬†So that was dope, next thing you know, Kane and Abel wanted to work, and I started working with them a lot. I went out there and I was on a song with them. KL was like, ‚ÄúForget that, bruh. I‚Äôm about to take you out there with me.‚Äù So, he took me and when you walk in, you walk straight and there is an office to your left and an office to your right and in the middle was a conference table. So, we were recording‚Ä¶ well, KL was in there making beats. I‚Äôm up in there chillin with him while he‚Äôs working on songs. He got headphones on and next thing you know, P opens the door and sticks his head in. I turn around and he was real dry like, ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs up.‚Äù I said what‚Äôs up back, and KL got headphones on, so I tell him, ‚ÄúYa man saying what‚Äôs up.‚Äù So, KL say what‚Äôs up and P was like, ‚ÄúSay KL, let me holla atcha.‚Äù He pull, KL in his office and I hear them having a disagreement. P wasn‚Äôt too keen on meeting new people in that manner. They talking amongst themselves and I hear, P like, ‚ÄúMan, who this dude is you bringing up in here,‚Äù and KL is like, ‚ÄúMan, I‚Äôm telling you, we need this dude, bruh. He wasn‚Äôt too mad on that type of level, but it caught him off guard or whatever. They were in there for a few minutes or whatever and he walked in and it got quiet again, but I remember them going in that room. KL opened the door and they walked up in there and he said, ‚ÄúYeah, everything cool, bruh.‚Äù He went back to making beats. I remember him bringing me up there every chance he could get. It was never like, ‚ÄúHey KL, can you bring me up there.‚Äù It was always him, ‚ÄúSay bruh, I think you need to be over here.‚Äù Mia, Kane and Abel and KL, made it official for me to go around. I never stopped going in. I used to get up with KL in his blue Suburban. His Dallas Cowboys blue Suburban, he was a die-hard Dallas Cowboys fan ya heard me. I don‚Äôt know how, but that‚Äôs his thing. We used to drive out there, bruh and it used to be like magic. I was there to see him produce ‚ÄúWatcha Think.‚Äù I was there for all of these situations. I was there for the finishing of the ‚ÄúBout It Bout It‚Äù soundtrack. It was just sick, man to know how dirty and grimy you can make music to represent the picture of our culture. It just threw me, bruh. ‚ÄúI gotta get a meal ticket.‚Äù I got to see that first hand, bruh. That‚Äôs the process that I didn‚Äôt mind waiting for when it came to time. That was the process because in between those times of waiting for whatever, I was able to record me an album, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs One In Every Family,‚Äù piece by piece by piece. AllHipHop.com: I think your debut cut, was one of the most arrogant debut singles ever and we loved it; ‚ÄúI‚Äôm The Baddest Motherfucker Alive!‚Äù Fiend: Bruh‚Ä¶ now that you say that, I never looked at it like‚Ä¶ those words. I never looked at it like, ‚ÄúMe, yeah, me, I‚Äôm the baddest.‚Äù It was just a phrase that was stuck in my head. I promise you, it was just a vibe and I‚Äôm happy I stuck to it and I‚Äôm happy DJ Precise didn‚Äôt hinder me because of the track. I‚Äôm happy that the people was around to say, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs make this happen.‚Äù I didn‚Äôt hinder myself. I just kept pushing. I didn‚Äôt hear the naysayers. I couldn‚Äôt hear nobody, but the sounds of me wanting to murder a track. That song happened on ‚ÄúBig Boy Records‚Äù and you can say the rest is history. I had a lot of ups and downs, but in the city, that one song‚Ä¶ it was no looking back, bruh. At the end of the day, bruh, I wanted to represent us so bad. I was going to be whatever I was going to be and I had it on my mind not to care about the judgement and just go. I had so much on my mind. I wish I could tell you I had this perfect blueprint, but I didn‚Äôt. All I knew was to work. Do the work, do the work, do the work. I never left the studio. That‚Äôs why I was on so much stuff. I‚Äôm just grateful. If my career was over with tomorrow or whatever the case may be I could be grateful knowing that I accomplished a lot of dope things, reached a lot of dope fans, met a lot of great new people, traveled the world and left an imprint. AllHipHop.com: I‚Äôm sure the opportunity to work with Snoop Dogg when he was signed to No Limit ranks high up there as well. Fiend: It was dope. Snoop is just an all-around dude and I am grateful for somebody like him. Not only being a fan at one time and growing to be friends, but I was able to see what it was like to have Love and Hip Hop before there was Love and Hip Hop. AllHipHop.com: When you see, C-Murder go do a bid, Mac, go do a bid, the unfortunate passing of, Mr. Magic, and you‚Äôre still here, you‚Äôre still doing what you love, one of the last Mohicans, so to speak. What is that feeling like? Fiend: You don‚Äôt know when it‚Äôs going to be your number. I‚Äôve seen some real close friends pass away and you just scratch your head. I‚Äôve been able to avoid a lot of things. Maybe I had a different right of passage something bigger for me to do. I don‚Äôt look at my life more greater than theirs, I just look at it like, I‚Äôve been preserved and it was on me to do something with it. I got low for a minute from a lot of things just being paranoid. People following you, special agents following you trying to take you down because of your success and your color. I don‚Äôt know why it was the agenda to focus on us like that, but it‚Äôs just real, man. Of course a lot of people are going to get it in my book and my documentary. It wasn‚Äôt an easy path. I never thought I would be here to be talking about, I‚Äôm still here. You get past 25 and you doing big business. That‚Äôs just really what it is. I‚Äôm just more in shock. I never thought I would be the dude saying, ‚ÄúBack in my day.‚Äù To still be in the heart of what‚Äôs poppin and the movement, ya know‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm grateful. AllHipHop.com: It was a pleasure speaking with you and I wish you continued success moving forward. Is there anything else to add before I let you go? Fiend: I appreciate your time, Mr. Crawford. I really appreciate your time. I want to be able to utilize the company and the outlet that you are working for more often. I would like to go about it using the correct procedure, so that I could be more consistent. I know that there are no promises behind it, but I have a lot of music and a lot of vibes and I want to be able to put it out there. I‚Äôm appreciative for all blogs and websites who show me support and follow me on social media. I think it helps to have great young writers that know the story and know how to get great stories out. If people can tune-in to me and follow me on Instagram @504fiend, Twitter @FIEND4DAMONEY, Facebook is 504Fiend or Richard Jones and Snap Chat is Fiend Whomp Whomp. If you got Pandora or Spotify, those type of outlets that you are streaming, visit me. I want you to look up my new brand, which is ‚ÄúInternational Jones.‚Äù That‚Äôs where we are going and that‚Äôs where we are headed and that‚Äôs where I want to be able to give people great music for the next how many years, I‚Äôll be able to do it.
Pics by Tim Sanchez and additional images by Ural Garrett
